loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy enough goods such as slippers, blouses, and trousers to sell.

loans.name: Flor De Chuti Estancia Group

texts.en:
The Friendship Bridge Trust Bank “Flor de Chuti Estancia” is composed of nine women and located in the rural area of San Andres Semetabaj, Guatemala. The ladies meet once each month with a Friendship Bridge Loan Officer to manage their loans and to participate in educational trainings. As many of them have had little or no education, they are pleased to have an opportunity to speak openly about issues like violence against women, discrimination, women’s rights as well as women’s health. During the trainings, the women can give their point of view or simply share their experiences. This helps them to improve their self-esteem. 

Maria is the President of the Trust Bank with eight children who range in age from 6 to 22. She is married to a bricklayer. Maria is a hard working woman and has a handicraft and textile business. She has regular clients and delivers products to them once each month. This allows her to have a regular, fixed income. She is requesting a loan that she will use to purchase additional raw materials including thread in bulk. She will be able to reduce her costs by taking advantage of offers and discounts.

Maria had no access to formal education but she understands the importance that education has in her life and for her own children. She is more prepared to successfully manage her loan and her business with the information that she receives at her Trust Bank meetings. Besides the topics mentioned above, Maria and her friends in the Trust Bank learn about effective business practices including accounting, budgeting, business planning, customer service, marketing and pricing. She supports and encourages her children to pursue their own studies because she realizes that education is a vital key to a successful future. One of her eight children will graduate from high school next year and Maria is quite thrilled about this!

Kiva investors play a key role in the lives of the nine women in the Trust Bank in funding their small loans. They face a more prosperous and brighter future as more aware and empowered women, committed to eliminating poverty in their lives. Thank you, Kiva investors!

loans.use: To purchase additional raw materials including thread in bulk for her craft business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more locks, hammers, nails, wire, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Kalameli

texts.en: Kalameli is 31 years old and unwed with 3 children. She owns and operates a small store selling a variety of items. She has been doing this for two years. Kalameli needs a loan to buy a new display fridge, a chest freezer, snacks, frozen goods, canned food, and sacks of onions and potatoes. She hopes to use her profits to pay for the renovation of her house and help pay for her children's education. She became a member of SPBD in 2012 to gain access to capital for her business.

loans.use: to buy a new display fridge, a chest freezer, snacks, frozen goods, canned food, and sacks of onions and potatoes.

loans.name: Ofisa

texts.en:
Ofisa is 40 years old and unwed with five children. She has a small plantation where she grows taro and bananas that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for four years. Ofisa needs a loan to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gumboots and a spade. 
 
She has been a member of SPBD since 2010 and will use the profits from her sales to pay for her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gumboots and a spade

loans.name: Fololina

texts.en: Fololina is a 20-year-old unmarried woman with one child. She makes and sells pancakes in her community to earn a living. She has two years of experience with this business. Fololina needs a loan to buy bags of flour, sugar, yeast, a large frying pan, a new oven and paper bags. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. Fololina just became a member of SPBD this year.

loans.use: to buy bags of flour, sugar, yeast, a large frying pan, a new oven and paper bags

loans.name: Vaiteelagi

texts.en: Vaiteelagi is 32 years old and unwed with one child. She has a small plantation where she grows taro and bananas that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for five years. Vaiteelagi needs a loan to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gumboots and a spade. She has been a member of SPBD since 2009. Vaiteelagi will use the profits from her sales to pay for her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gumboots and a spade

loans.name: Seiaute

texts.en: Seiaute is 26 years old and unwed with three children. She has a small plantation where she grows taro that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for three years. Seiaute needs a loan to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gumboots and a spade. She has been a member of SPBD since 2011. Seiaute will use the profits from her sales to pay for her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gumboots and a spade

loans.name: Artesanas Santa Catarina Group

texts.en:
Santa Catarina Palopo is a small town built on a steep hillside on the shores of Lake Atitlan in Guatemala. Those who live there are Maya-Kakchikel and proudly practice their cultural and linguistic traditions. The women wear particularly beautiful “traje” or traditional costume, in shades of blues and greens. 

The Friendship Bridge Trust Bank “Artesanas Santa Catarina” meaning “Artisans from Santa Catarina” was formed here and consists of seven dedicated and hardworking women. They share the common goal of creating more successful and prosperous lives for themselves and their families. Petrona is one of them and she is a shining example of a woman who has worked very hard and made a success of herself. She is 43-years-old and has seven children. Two of her children, who were in school, have already graduated. Petrona makes high end textiles and sells them in tourist markets throughout Guatemala. Because of the excellent quality of her work, her products enjoy high demand. Petrona is requesting a loan that she will use to increase her inventory. From other vendors, she wants to purchase bags and purses of various sizes, scarves, shawls, belts, typical blouses called “huipiles” as well as supplies for her own textile business including thread. Petrona employs seven women in the community of Santa Catarina who are motivated, skilled and have a good work ethic. The ladies are most pleased to have employment.

“Microcredit Plus” is the name that Friendship Bridge gives to the combination of small loans and participatory education. Each month, a Loan Officer from the organization shares timely information with Petrona and the ladies in the Trust Bank about relevant topics like women’s rights, violence against women and self-esteem, effective business management practices as well as hygiene, health and nutrition. 

Petrona and each of the women in the Trust Bank appreciate the support of Kiva investors. They are determined to use their loans wisely, to empower themselves and eliminate poverty. Being able to access capital is so very important to them. Thank you, Kiva investors!

loans.use: to increase her inventory.

loans.name: Benkadi 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe BENKADI 1 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 50 ans, ont en moyenne 4 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles traditionnelles à  N'GOLONIENA  un village dans la commune de LOBOUGOULA dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du MALI.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur septième prêt de campagne avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est l’arachide avec madame MARIAM débout à la deuxième position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe de femme BENKADI 1. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter 1 sac de 50 kg d’engrais, 1 bidon d’herbicide, payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  0, 5 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant et à crédit.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 73 000 francs CFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et son intérêt, aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The ten members of the BENKADI 1 group are married women and they are, on average, 50 years old with four children each. Most of them live in traditional families in N'goloniena, a village located in the commune of Lobougoula, Cercle of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They work with Kiva's partner, the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, in order to successfully carry out their farming activities during the rainy season. They are on their seventh farming loan with the institution and have duly repaid their previous loans.

Mariam, a member of the group, grows groundnut. In the photo, she is in the back row, second from the left. She is planning to use her loan to buy one 50-kilo bag of fertilizers, one can of herbicide, and also to cover the cost of plowing to maintain 0.5 hectare of land. After the harvest, she sells her crop in her village and in Sikasso. She sells to both men and women and gets paid in cash and on credit. Mariam is expecting to make an average profit of 73,000 CFA francs per planting season. She will use her profit to repay her loan and the interest, and also to help her husband with the day-to-day expenses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, herbicides, and to cover her plowing costs

loans.name: Iulia

texts.en: Iulia is 48 years old and unmarried with 5 children. She has a small plantation where she grows taro and bananas that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for two years. Iulia needs a loan to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gumboots and a spade. She has been a member of SPBD since 2012. Iulia will use the profits from her sales to pay for her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gumboots and a spade.

loans.name: Mauai

texts.en: Mauai is 42 years old and married with five children. She has a small vegetable garden where she grows cabbages and tomatoes that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for three years. Mauai needs a loan to buy insect poison, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gloves and a watering hose. She has been a member of SPBD since 2011. Mauai will use the profits from her sales to pay for her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy insect poison, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gloves and a watering hose

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
Nena is 35-years-old and lives in Silanga, Tangub City. She is married with three children. Nena sells fish in the neighborhood to earn a living. 

Nena has sought her additional capital from PMPC. She applied for a loan to buy more fish to sell. In the future, Nena would like to improve their living conditions and to be able to send all her children to school.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Ulufale

texts.en: Ulufale is 41 years old and unwed with 3 children. She owns and operates a small store selling a variety of items. She has been doing this for 2 years. Ulufale needs a loan to buy a new display fridge, a chest freezer, snacks, frozen goods, canned food, a sack of onions and a new hanging scale. She hopes to use her profits to pay for her children's education. She became a member of SPBD this year to gain access to capital for her business.

loans.use: to buy a new display fridge, a chest freezer, snacks, frozen goods, canned food, a sack of onions and a new hanging scale.

loans.name: Benkadi 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe  BENKADI 1 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans, ont en moyenne 5 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles traditionnelles à NIARADOUGOU un village dans la commune de DANDERESSO dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du MALI.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de campagne avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été correctement remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est de riz avec madame FATOUMATA débout à la deuxième position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe de femme BENKADI 1. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter 2 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 1 bidon d’herbicide, payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  0, 5 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant et à crédit.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 74 000 francs CFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et son intérêt, aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The ten members of the BENKADI 1 group are married women and they are, on average, 40 years old with five children each. Most of them live in traditional families in Niaradougou, a village located in the commune of Danderesso, Cercle of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They work with Kiva's partner, the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, in order to successfully carry out their farming activities during the rainy season. They are on their fifth farming loan with the institution and have duly repaid their previous loans.

Fatoumata, a member of the group, is a rice farmer.  In the photo, she is in the back row, second from the left. She is planning to use her loan to buy two 50-kilo bags of fertilizers, one can of herbicide, and also to cover the cost of plowing to maintain 0.5 hectare of land. After the harvest, she sells her crop in her village and in Sikasso. She sells to both men and women and gets paid in cash and on credit.  Fatoumata is expecting to make an average profit of 74,000 CFA francs per planting season. She will use her profit to repay her loan and the interest, and also to help her husband with the day-to-day expenses of the family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and herbicides, and to cover her plowing costs.

loans.name: Emee

texts.en:
Emee works hard to support her family. She is married and has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her business.

Emee has been in this business for 10 years now.

In the future, Emee would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her motorcycle

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en: Lolita is married with 4 children. Lolita is 56 years old and lives in Dolores, Clarin, Philippines. Lolita is a farmer and grows corn crops to earn a living. She has been doing this for 10 years. She has requested a loan to buy four sacks of fertilizer and insecticide. Lolita has been a member of PMPC for 7 years. In the future, Lolita hopes to expand her corn plantation.

loans.use: to buy four sacks of fertilizer and insecticide.

loans.name: Zeneida

texts.es:
Zenaida tiene 33 años de edad, reside en el Caserío de Polvazal, una comunidad rural del distrito de Morropon, una comunidad de clima caluroso, su población se dedica a la agricultura, comercio y ganadería, ubicada en la Provincia del mismo nombre que pertenece a la Región Piura, costa norte del Perú.

Ella se dedica a la venta de cerveza, piqueos, bebidas y otros, su bodega está ubicada en su domicilio, ha solicitado un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 1 000 nuevos soles para la compra de mayor cantidad de productos para ofrecer a sus clientes y de esta manera generar mayores ingresos para su familia.
texts.en: Zenaida is 33 years old and lives in Caserio de Polvazal, a rural community in the Morropon district. It's a community with a warm climate, whose population works in agriculture, business, and livestock. It's located in the province that bears the same name in the Piura region on Peru's northern coast. She works in the sale of beer, snacks, beverages and more. Her store is located inside her home, and she's requested a loan of 1,000 nuevos soles from Edypme Alternative to purchase a larger amount of products to sell to her customers and that way generate a higher income for her family.

loans.use: To purchase different types of products to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Margarita Del Pilar

texts.es:
Margarita del Pilar tiene 35 años de edad, vive en el distrito de Zaña, una comunidad de clima variado, su población se dedica a la agricultura, comercio y ganadería, ubicada en la Provincia de Chiclayo que pertenece a la Región Lambayeque, costa norte del Perú.

Ella se dedica a la venta de alimentos preparados y cerveza, cuenta con clientes que la conocen por la buena sazón de sus platos, ha solicitado un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 1 500 nuevos soles para la compra de insumos de sus alimentos y de esta manera seguir preparando sus platos.
texts.en: Margarita del Pilar is 35 years old and lives in the Zana district, a community with a varied climate and whose population works in agriculture, business and livestock. It's located in the Chiclayo province which is in the Lambayeque region in Peru's northern coast. She works selling cooked meals and beer, and is renowned amongst her customers for the good taste of her dishes. She has requested a loan of 1,500 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa to purchase supplies for her food so that she can continue making her dishes.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for the dishes she makes to sell to her customers

loans.name: Doraliza

texts.es:
Doraliza tiene 58 años de edad, vive junto a su esposo en el distrito de Cayaltí, una comunidad de clima variado, su población se dedica a la agricultura, comercio y ganadería, ubicada en la Provincia de Chiclayo que pertenece a la Región Lambayeque, costa norte del Perú.

Ella se dedica a la cría de animales de corral (chivos y carneros), su negocio se encuentra ubicado en la parte posterior de su domicilio, ha solicitado un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 500 nuevos soles para la compra de cerdos pequeños para cría y de esta manera generar mayores ingresos para su familia.
texts.en:
Doraliza is 58 years old and lives with her husband in the Cayalti district, a community with a varied climate. Its population works in agriculture, business, and raising livestock. The location is in the Chiclayo province of the Lambayeque region on Peru's northern coast. 
She works in raising barnyard animals (goats and rams), and her business is located in the rear part of her home. She has requested a loan from Edpyme Alternative in the amount of 500 nuevos soles to purchase small pigs to raise and in this way generate more income for her family.

loans.use: To purchase small pigs to fatten up and subsequently sell to customers.

loans.name: Faalata

texts.en:
Faalata, 27, is single. For the past three years she has made and sold pancakes in her community to help support her family.

Faalata has been a member of SPBD since 2011. She is applying for a 1,000 WST loan to buy bags of flour, a bag of sugar, cooking oil, a large frying pan and a new oven for her pancake business. She plans to use her profits to help pay her family’s weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her pancake business.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is married and works hard to support her family. For the past three years she has sold fish to earn an income.

Ruth is applying for a 8,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy fish to sell. Her ambition is to see her business grow and thrive.

loans.use: to buy fish to sell.

loans.name: Jinky

texts.en:
Jinky is thankful for the financial assistance extended to her. She was able to buy more products for her ready-to-wear business. She was also able to help her family in their everyday expenses at home. She continues to work hard to provide for her everyday needs and to be able to help her family.

She would like to apply for another loan, this time for 15,000 PHP, to buy additional stock of merchandise, such as pants and children's, men's and women's clothing, needed in her business. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Jinky dreams that her business will continue to flourish and hopes to help her family to improve their quality of living. She meets up every week with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for ready to wear products and merchandise items like women’s clothes, handkerchiefs, kid's shoes, towels and other products to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Elisapeta

texts.en: Elisapeta is a 62-year-old widow with seven children. She has a small plantation where she grows taro and bananas that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for 12 years. Elisapeta needs a loan to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gumboots and a spade. She has been a member of SPBD since 2002. Elisapeta will use the profits from her sales to pay for her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gumboots and a spade

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en:
Nelia is 50 years old and has eight children. Nelia is married and has three children who are in school.

Nelia and her family survived super typhoon Haiyan which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013, but her business and family home were wiped out. 

Nelia is taking out a housing loan amounting to PHP 9,720 to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor to build a house for her family. 

Nelia has been with NWTF since 2012. She plans to recover through her food vending business.

With your help, Nelia can rebuild her house and rebound from the devastation of super typhoon Haiyan. In future she would like to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase building materials and pay for construction labor.

loans.name: Violie

texts.en:
Violie is 37 years old, married and has four children, three of whom are in school. She and her family survived super typhoon Haiyan, which swept through the Philippines last November 8, 2013, but her business and family home were wiped out. She is now in business again selling vegetables.

Violie has been a NWTF client since 2012. She is applying for a 9,066 PHP housing loan to buy construction materials and pay for labor to build a house for her family.

With your help, Violie can rebuild her house and rebound from the devastation of super typhoon Haiyan. Her goals include saving enough money to further expand her business and send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy construction materials and pay for labor to build a house

loans.name: Lea

texts.en:
Lea, 34, is married and has three children who are in school. For the past twelve years she has worked hard catching and selling fish.

Lea is applying for a 15,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy a new engine for her fishing boat. Her goals include saving enough money to further expand her business and send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy a new engine for her fishing boat.

loans.name: Erika Lorena

texts.es:
La señora Erika es una persona muy trabajadora y responsable vive en una comunidad al sur de Honduras junto a su familia. Su negocio es la venta de ropa y zapatos clasificados desde hace 5 años.
Doña Erika su negocio lo tiene en su casa de habitación y necesita el préstamo para la compra de blusas, faldas, vestidos, camisas, pantalones, calzonetas, zapatos, etc. y tener la mercadería necesaria para la venta, con el préstamo espera le sirva de mucho ya que no cuenta con los productos necesarios para cubrir los pedidos solicitados por sus clientes y su vez poder mejorar la calidad de vida de la familia con el aumento de los ingresos en el hogar.
Uno de sus sueños es que en un corto plazo hacer crecer su negocio y  con esto poder seguir apoyando a su familia y que su hijo tengan los estudios necesarios, para que puedan tener mayores oportunidades en la vida.


Choluteca, Honduras – Julio  del  2014
texts.en:
Erika is a hardworking and responsible person. She lives in a community in the south of Honduras with her family.  She owns a business in which she has been selling clothing and shoes for the last five years. Erika runs this business out of her home. She needs this loan to buy blouses, skirts, dresses, shirts, pants, bathing suits, and shoes, etc. to have the merchandise necessary to make sales. Erika hopes this loan will help her since she currently does not have the products she needs to cover the orders requested by her customers. She hopes to be able to improve her family's quality of life with this increase in household income. 

One of Erika's short-term dreams is to expand her business so that she is able to support her family and her son can get an education so that he has better opportunities in life. 

Choluteca, Honduras – July  2014

loans.use: to buy blouses, skirts, dresses, shirts, pants, swimsuits, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda is married and works hard to help provide for her family, especially her two children. For the past ten years she has run her own “sari-sari,” or variety store, and has made a good living doing so.

Merlinda has taken out and successfully repaid previous loans for her business through CCT. To improve sales she is applying for a 16,000 PHP loan to buy additional quantities and varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages to sell.

Merlinda is determined to earn a greater income so she can better provide for her family. She sincerely wishes to give you heartfelt thanks and appreciation for any assistance in advance.

All CCT community clients, including Merlinda, are organized into fellowship groups of fifteen to thirty members who meet on a weekly basis. There they share stories of their work, repay microfinance loans and draw strength and inspiration from their study of the Word of God.

loans.use: to buy more stock for her shop.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah works hard to support her family. She is married and has a buy-and-sell rice business in the Philippines. She requested a 8,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy an additional sack of rice to sell. 

Sarah has been in this business for two years now, and in the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy an additional sack of rice to sell.

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie is 52 years old and single. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Elsie has a general store in the Philippines, and she requested a 10,000 PHP loan through NWTF in order to buy more groceries to sell. Elsie has been in this business for 23 years, and in the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Maria Felix

texts.es:
La señora María es una persona muy trabajadora y responsable vive en una comunidad al sur de Honduras junto a su familia. Su negocio es la venta de tortillas, desde hace 10 años, la cual funciona en su casa de habitación en el municipio donde vive. 
Doña María necesita el préstamo para la compra de más insumos como maíz, leña y cal para seguir elaborando sus tortillas y aumentar la producción de su negocio, el cual le ayuda mucho ya que las ganancias son de mucha utilidad en el hogar. Con el préstamo espera que sus ventas aumenten de forma considerablemente y así satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes.
Doña María  también espera poder mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia con el aumento de los ingresos en el hogar y en un corto plazo hacer crecer su negocio y  con esto poder seguir apoyando a sus hijos con los estudios para que pueda tener mayores oportunidades en la vida. 


Choluteca, Honduras – Julio del  2014
texts.en:
Maria is a very hard working and responsible person who lives with her family in a community in southern Honduras. Her business for the past 10 years has been selling tortillas which she runs out of her home in the city where she lives.

Maria needs the loan to buy more inputs like corn, firewood and lime to continue making tortillas and to increase her business output. This helps her a lot since the earnings are very useful in her household. With this loan she hopes her sales will increase considerably and thus satisfy her customer’s demands.
Maria also hopes to be able to improve her family’s quality of life with the increase in her household income and in the short term to make her business grow. With this she can continue supporting her children’s schooling so that they can have greater opportunities in life.

Choluteca, Honduras – July, 2014

loans.use: to buy corn, firewood and lime for her business.

loans.name: Lanie

texts.en: Lanie is 38 years old, and married with three children. All of her children attend school. She is a retail store owner while her spouse provides motorcycle transportation services in their village. Lanie wanted to increase her income and is in need for additional merchandise to offer. She is now asking for a loan of 18,000 PHP to buy canned goods, biscuits, soap, coffee and sugar to sell. She hopes this loan will be given to her to supplement her capital and and hopes to someday achieve progression.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, biscuits, soap, coffee and sugar to sell.

loans.name: Mildred

texts.en:
Mildred is 65 years old and married with five children. 

Mildred works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 13,000 PHP loan through NWTF in order to buy more groceries to sell.

Mildred has borrowed and repaid seven loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for five years and also earns an income from rice retailing. 

Mildred aspires to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Richie

texts.en:
Richie is a married woman with three children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Richie is 43 years old and all of her children are in school.

Richie has a natural medicines business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 19,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy more natural medicines and vitamins to offer for sale.

Richie has been in this business for thee years. In the future, Richie would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more natural medicines and vitamins to offer for sale.

loans.name: Baatar

texts.en:
Mr. Baatar is 42 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He is a railroad worker who maintains railroad tracks, and he has been working at a train station since 1992. His wife also works at a train station as a dispatcher. Their two children both go to high school. 

The house that Baatar and his family live in has deteriorated over the years and needs some repair. Therefore, he is requesting a loan of 3,500,000 MNT to buy building materials such as bricks, cement, fiberglass and foam. After renovation, his family will live in a comfortable and warm place where less coal is burned and less pollutants are released into the air. Baatar is a very hardworking individual who strives for a better future.

loans.use: to buy building materials.

loans.name: Limalau

texts.en: Limalau is a 33-year-old married woman with five children. She makes and sells ice cakes in her community to earn a living. She has three years of experience with this business. Limalau needs a loan to buy cordials, sugar, a large cooler, a large spoon, foam cups and chinese candy. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. Limalau has been a member of SPBD since 2011.

loans.use: to buy cordials, sugar, a large cooler, a large spoon, foam cups and chinese candy.

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida is 50 years old and has three children. She is married and all of her children are in school.

Aida is in the agricultural business, pig fattening in the Philippines. Aida requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Aida has been in the pig-fattening business for eight years now and has borrowed six times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Aida would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Merlelyn

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Merlelyn works hard to support her family.

She has a restaurant business in the Philippines and earns additional income from motorcycle transport. Merlelyn is borrowing PHP 30,000 through NWTF to buy more ingredients like canned goods, fish, vegetables, etc for her restaurant business.

Merlelyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past 16 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more ingredients like canned goods, fish, and vegetables

loans.name: Elmer

texts.en:
Elmer, 43 years old, is married. He has been engaged in a farming business for eight years. He is a very responsible father to his family. He loves to cook food and serve it to his children. 

Elmer is asking for a loan amounting to 15,000 Philippines pesos to buy seed and fertilizer. The farming business is where he gets all the needs of his family.

In the future, Elmer hopes that he can purchase another land to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy seed and fertilizer for his farm business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs to help her coffee crop this season.

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia is 49 years old and married with six children.

Amalia works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 12,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Amalia has borrowed and repaid five loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for three years and also earns an income from rice retailing.

Amalia aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Ma. Brinlle

texts.en:
Ma. Brinlle is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fishing business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 28,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to buy fishing materials for the maintenance of her fishing business.

Ma. Brinlle has been in this business for two years. Ma. Brinlle earns more income from buying and selling fish.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college in the future.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials for the maintenance of her business

loans.name: Ana Fe

texts.en:
Ana Fe is 32 years old and married with five children.

Ana Fe works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 12,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to buy additional items like canned goods, soft drinks, snack foods, coffee, sugar, cereals, etc., to sell.

Ana Fe has borrowed and paid two loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for three years and also earns an income from food vending.

Ana Fe aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional items like canned goods, soft drinks, snack foods, coffee, sugar, cereals, etc., to sell

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fishing business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 20,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to purchase additional fishing net for her fishing business.

Lourdes has been in this business for one year. Lourdes earns more income from buying and selling fish.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and now she requested an additional loan to further build her business.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials for her business.

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en:
Loreta has faithfully paid back her previous loan, which she used for her business. She has been operating her business for years and she earns well from this. Having a bigger responsibility requires more effort to provide for their needs, especially for her children. She had to work hard, with the determination of having a better income to provide for her family. 

To improve her profit, Loreta would like to apply for a new loan. With PHP 10,000, she could already purchase more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and other materials for her business. She sincerely lets you know her heartfelt thanks and appreciation for this assistance in advance.

Loreta dreams of having more customers and hopes to be always fit for work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week. She draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw materials like fabric and thread

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
This is Josie, who is 49 years old and married with three kids. Josie and her husband help each other to manage their farm. Josie is the one who monitors for the financial needs, while her husband is the one who always checks the status of their farm. They both love their family. They make sure that they give all the needs of their family. 

Josie is requesting a loan amounting to 15,000 Philippines pesos to buy two sacks of fertilizer, manure, pesticide and seed so that she can have additional income to serve to her children in their allowances and daily needs in the future.

Josie dreams that she can see her children finish their studies.

loans.use: to buy two sacks of fertilizer, manure, pesticide and seed

loans.name: Polina

texts.en: Polina is a Babban Gona farmer from Yan Gwari. Polina expressed that she is driven by one goal: to “make more money for myself and my family.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Polina to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, she finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Polina can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Polina is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Polina will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what she plans to do with her income from this season, she said: “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family”. With this loan, Polina will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Hauwa

texts.en: Hauwa is a 38 year old farmer from Yan Gwari. As a Babban Gona member, Hauwa, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Hauwa can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Hauwa is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Hauwa said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland, in 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, Hauwa is on her way to achieving this dream

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Joselito

texts.en: Joselito is a married man who is engaged in the farming business. He is a very hardworking person. Every morning he checks his farm so that he can monitor his crops. To have additional income, Joselito is asking for a loan of PHP 15,000 to buy manure, fertilizer and seeds for his farm business, so that he can provide all the needs of his children in a cropping season.

loans.use: to buy manure, fertilizer and seeds for his farm business.

loans.name: San Roque Group

texts.es:
San Roque forma parte del programa de eliminación de la pobreza, a través del cual, las integrantes podrán conocer la situación en la que cada una se encuentra, y conforme a ello ir mejorando las condiciones de vida de cada familia.
Una de las integrantes es la Sra. Norma, quien cada día lucha a través de las ventas de prendas que hace, es una mujer muy trabajadoras que empieza su día muy tempranas horas del día. A través de las capacitaciones ha podido crecer e ir mejorando sus condiciones de vida y la de su familia.
Norma pide este préstamo ya que con el podrá comprar una mayor variedad de prendas, y así seguir luchando por mejorar sus ingresos y con lo cual podrá seguir ayudando a sus seres queridos que son su familia.
texts.en:
“San Roque” is a group that is participating in the poverty elimination program. The purpose of the program is to help the members become familiar with each of their situations so that they can make adjustments to improve the living conditions of their families.

One of the members is Sra. Norma. Each day she strives to sell the clothes that she produces herself. This hardworking woman begins her day very early in the morning. With the training she received, Norma is able to grow and improve her living conditions and those of her family.

She is requesting a loan in order to buy a wide variety of clothes. As a result, she can continue to improve her earnings so that she can keep supporting her loved ones, especially her family.

loans.use: to buy a variety of clothes to sell.

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en:
Anecita is a married woman with four children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Anecita is 53 years old and has two children who are still in school.

Anecita has a general store business in the Philippines. Anecita requested a PHP 25,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store.

Anecita has been in this business for 10 years. Anecita would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Delyn

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Delyn works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling fish. Delyn is borrowing 25,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to buy additional fishing materials for her fishing business.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and now she requested an additional loan to further build her business.

Delyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past nine loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional fishing materials

loans.name: Adora

texts.en:
Adora is 37 years old and married with five children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Adora is borrowing 10,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to buy additional feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

Adora has been raising pigs for six years and also earns additional income from food vending.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional feeds and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Cheepe

texts.en:
Cheepe works hard to support three children. She is married and has a food vending business in the Philippines.

Cheepe requested a 4,600 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF in order to buy a solar lamp.

She is getting the solar lamp because she wants to save money by minimizing her kerosene expenses.

Cheepe is aware that by using the solar lamp, she is not only saving money, she is also helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

loans.use: to buy a solar lamp.

loans.name: Carina

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Carina works hard to support her family.

She has a buying and selling of vegetables business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling charcoal. Carina is borrowing 15,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to buy vegetables to sell in her food stall for her buying and selling of vegetables business.

Carina has been sustaining her business activities through her past 15 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy vegetables to sell in her food stall

loans.name: Hannatu Samaila

texts.en: Hannatu Samaila is a 37 year old farmer from Yan Gwari. As a Babban Gona member, Hannatu Samaila is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Hannatu Samaila can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Hannatu Samaila, is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Hannatu Samaila said “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family, in 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs.” With this loan, Hannatu Samaila is on her way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Filomiya

texts.en: Filomiya remembers the extreme poverty that her family faced  during a particularly bad harvest. This is before she became a Babban Gona Member. Now, as a Babban Gona member, Filomiya like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the National average of 14. However, Filomiya is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  Filomiya expressed that “In 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, Filomiya is well on her way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Hannatu

texts.en: Hannatu remembers the extreme poverty that her family faced during a particularly bad harvest. This was before she became a Babban Gona member. Now, Hannatu, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Hannatu is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty”, expressed Hannatu.  With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Epenesa

texts.en: Epenesa is 24 years old and married with 3 children. She has a small vegetable garden where she grows tomatoes that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for 4 years. Epenesa needs a loan to buy insect poison, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gloves and a watering hose. She has been a member of SPBD since 2010. Epenesa will use the profits from her sales to pay for her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy insect poison, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gloves and a watering hose.

loans.name: Maryamu

texts.en: Maryamu is a 40 year old farmer from Yan Gwari. As a Babban Gona member, Maryamu is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Maryamu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. Maryamu expects to double the national average and yield 30 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Maryamu said “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family, in 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, Maryamu is on her way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Carlos Jose

texts.es: Carlos José: Es un señor trabajador, originario de Waspan, tiene 47 años de edad, casado, con 3 hijos que estudian su primaria. Cuenta con una experiencia de más de dos décadas de ser docente.  Con el propósito de vivir de manera segura y digna, desde hace 4 años ha iniciado la construcción de su vivienda de minifalda de concreto y madera. Solicita financiamiento, para construir poco a poco su vivienda y comprar materiales de construcción: bloques, cemento, hierro, madera, zinc, clavos y cubrir costos de mano de obra. Su sueño es tener una vivienda segura con las condiciones adecuadas y velar por la educación de su hijo.
texts.en:
Carlos José is a hardworking man who is originally from Waspan. He is 47 years old, married, and has three children who are in primary school. Carlos has more than two decades of experience as a teacher. With the intent of living securely and decently, he started four years ago the construction of his “minifalda” (a structural design that can withstand earthquakes) house made of concrete and wood.

Carlos José is requesting a loan so that he can gradually build his home and purchase construction materials such as blocks, cement, iron, wood, zinc, and nails. He will also cover the cost of labor. His dreams are to have a secure home with adequate conditions and to provide for his children’s education.

loans.use: to buy construction materials and to pay for labor.

loans.name: Saratu

texts.en: Saratu is a Babban Gona farmer from Yan Gwari. Saratu is driven by one goal: to “ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty.” It is this ambition that led Saratu to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, she finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Saratu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. Saratu is expecting to reap at least 30 bags per hectare this season because with this loan, she will finally be able to access the required yield enhancing inputs such as improved seeds. Saratu is hoping that as a result of this expected yield, she will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what changes she would like to make, she said “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family.  Ultimately, I want to ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty.” With this loan, Saratu will be able to access all the inputs and services to make these dreams reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Hannatu

texts.en: Hannatu is a 30-year-old farmer from Yan Gwari.  As a Babban Gona member, Hannatu, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist.  Like all Babban Gona members, Hannatu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Hannatu is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Hannatu said “I plan to use the money I make to educate my children: Barnabas, Mercy, and Patrick, and in 5 years, I want to ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty”. With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Valasi

texts.en: Valasi is 35 years old and married with two children. She has a small vegetable garden where she grows cabbages and tomatoes that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for 4 years. Valasi needs a loan to buy insect poison, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gloves and a watering hose. She has been a member of SPBD since 2010. Valasi will use the profits from her sales to pay for her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy insect poison, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gloves and a watering hose.

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia owns and operates a buy-and-sell business. She has been successful in this business for six years, and she repaid her previous loan used for the business. She also finds ways to improve her income to provide for their everyday needs and necessities.

Relative to this, she would like to take out a new loan to buy additional stocks of stuffed toys and other products needed in her business. She is requesting an amount of PHP 8,000, and hoping to improve her profit from the business. 

She sincerely expresses her heartfelt thanks and appreciation for this assistance in advance.

Cecilia hopes to increase her profit and build more capital. She also dreams for her child to have a good life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members* to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay back Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy an additional stock of supplies and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys works hard to support her family. Gladys is single and has a food vending business in the Philippines.

Gladys is borrowing PHP 1,800 through NWTF in order to buy a solar lamp.

She is getting the solar lamp because she wants to have backup light in case of emergency.

Gladys is aware that by using the solar lamp, she is saving money, helping the environment and reducing health and hazard risks to her family.

loans.use: to buy a solar lamp.

loans.name: Patirisha

texts.en: Patirisha is a 26 year old farmer from Yan Gwari. As a Babban Gona member, Patirisha is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Patirisha can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. Patirisha is aiming to reap at least 30 bags per hectare this season, double the national average of 14. When asked, Patirisha said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland, in 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, Patirisha is on her way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield
