Now, Mary, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Mary is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community”, expressed Mary. With this loan, Mary is well on her way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Maryamu

texts.en: Maryamu is a 35 year old farmer from Yan Gwari. As a Babban Gona member, Maryamu, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Maryamu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Maryamu is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Maryamu said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland, in 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, Maryamu is on her way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: Maria es una mujer trabajadora, soltera y no tiene hijos. Ella vive en La Paz en una casa de ladrillo y cemento donde paga un alquiler Maria es artesana, se dedica especificamente a elaborar zapatos Recientemente Maria fue victima de robo por lo que necesita un prestamo para invertir en su negocio de zapatos, comprando materiales e instrumentos Maria es una mujer sola por lo que necesita su ayuda
texts.en:
Maria is a hardworking woman who is single and has no children. She lives in La Paz in a house of brick and cement which she rents. 

Maria is an artisan and makes shoes. She was recently the victim of a burglary, so she now needs a loan to invest in her shoe business and buy material and tools. Maria is a single woman, which is why she needs a loan.

loans.use: to invest in her shoe business by buying material and tools

loans.name: Domecita

texts.en:
As the married parent of six children, Domecita works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling fish. She is borrowing PHP 18,000 through NWTF to purchase fishing net for her fishing business.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and now she has requested an additional loan to further build her business.

Domecita has been sustaining her business activities through her past eight loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fishing net

loans.name: Rashila

texts.en: Rashila is a Babban Gona farmer from Yan Gwari. Rashila is driven by one goal: to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is this ambition that led Rashila to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, she finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Rashila can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Rashila is ambitious and is aiming to reap close to 35 bags per hectare this season because with this loan, she will finally be able to access the required yield enhancing inputs such as improved seeds. Rashila is hoping that as a result of this expected yield, she will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what changes she would like to make, she said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland." With this loan, Rashila will be able to access all the inputs and services to make these dreams reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Uwalle

texts.en: Uwalle is a 30-year-old farmer from Barau.  As a Babban Gona member, Uwalle is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Uwalle can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. Uwalle is aiming to reap close to 30 bags per hectare this season, double the national average of 14.  When asked how she plans to spend the income she will make as a Babban Gona member, she said, “I plan to use the money  to educate my children: Alhamdu, Absalam, and  Jilios. My overall goal is to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Giang

texts.en:
Giang is 27 years old and married with 2 children. She lives with 2 dependents in Quang Xuong district, a rural town in Thanh Hoa province.

She operates a food stall/restaurant selling fish. She has been involved in this business for 6 years. This is her first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

The main hardship that Giang faces in her life is not having a latrine, so her family has to share their neighbor's latrine. Therefore she is requesting a loan to purchase sand, cement and bricks to build a toilet.

Giang hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, for her business to do well, and to make enough money to provide for her kids.

loans.use: to purchase sand, cement and bricks to build a toilet

loans.name: Jonathan

texts.en: Jonathan is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Jonathan joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Hadiza, Helin, and  Ezikiel. Jonathan is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Jonathan will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Jonathan can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/hectare: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to build a better home.” Jonathan is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Salomi

texts.en: Salomi is a maize farmer from Barau.  As a Babban Gona member, Salomi is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Salomi can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. As a Babban Gona farmer, Salomi can reap up to 30 bags/hectare,  double the national average of 14.  When asked how she plans to spend the income she will make as a Babban Gona member, she said, “I plan to use the money  to educate my children: Debora, Abigel, and  Alhamdu. My overall goal is to make more money for myself and my family”. With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Erickson

texts.en:
This is Erickson, who is 43 years old and married with two kids. He is a hardworking and loving person. 

Erickson is dedicated to his business and he loves what he does. He says that his father taught him how to cultivate a farm.

Erickson hopes that he can see all his kids finish their studies. For this reason, he is asking for a loan amounting to PHP 15,000 to buy fertilizer, seeds and pesticide for his farm business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, seeds and pesticide for his farm business

loans.name: Seela

texts.en:
Seela is a 53-year-old widow with 9 children. 

She has a small plantation where she grows taro and bananas that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for 4 years. 

Seela needs a loan to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gum boots and lots of crops. She will use the profits from her sales to pay for her family's weekly expenses.
 
She has been a member of SPBD since 2010.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gum boots and lots of crops

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita is a married woman with five children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Angelita is 48 years old and has two children who are currently in school.

Angelita has a business buying and selling dry goods in the Philippines. Angelita requested a loan of PHP 13000 through NWTF to purchase more stocks of dry goods to sell.

Angelita has been in this business for 15 years. In the future, Angelita would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of dry goods to sell

loans.name: Marijha

texts.en:
Marijha is a 38-year-old married woman with three children who are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Marijha has an internet café business in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 30,000 loan amount through NWTF in order to buy computer supplies. She has been in this business for four years. 

In the future, Marijha would like to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy computer supplies.

loans.name: Gambo

texts.en: Gambo is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Gambo joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Anas, Yusufa, and  Harisu. Gambo is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Gambo will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Gambo can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to build a better home.” Gambo is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “make more money for myself and my family”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to increase her general store.

loans.name: Angel Elias

texts.es:
Angel tiene 32 años de edad vive en el cantón San Miguel provincia de Bolivar, en la comunidad Ambrocio Laso su estado civil es casado vive con su esposa y sus hijos de 12 y 10 años.
Es integrante de la Ventanilla Rural Ambrocio Laso.
Angel se dedica a la siembra de papas habas y a la crianza de chonchos.
Con el dinero del crédito le servirá para sembrar y comprar líquidos y abonos para los cultivos con el apoyo del crédito puede incrementar el negoció ,realiza sus compras en las ciudades de chimbo cada semana,su sueño y metas que tiene es comprar un terreno para seguir cultivando los desafíos que enfrenta es las plagas,en su tiempo libre hace deporte.
texts.en:
Angel is 32 years old and lives in the canton of San Miguel in the Bolivar province, specifically in the community of Ambrocio Laso. He is married and lives with his wife and children who are 12 and 10 years of age.  Angel is a member of the Ventanilla Rural Ambrocio Laso group. He grows potatoes and beans and raises pigs. 

The money from this loan will be used to sow the land and buy liquids and fertiliser for his crops. With the help of this loan Angel will be able to expand his business and make purchases in the city of Chimbo each week. His dream and goal is to buy land to continue growing crops. The challenges he faces are plagues. In his free time Angel plays sport.

loans.use: to buy agricultural fertilisers

loans.name: Auwalu

texts.en: Auwalu is a Babban Gona farmer from Tafida. Auwalu is driven by one goal: to “ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs.” It is this ambition that led Auwalu to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Auwalu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. As a Babban Gona farmer, Auwalu can yield up to 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. Auwalu is hoping that as a result of this expected yield, he will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what changes he would like to make, he said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland.  Ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs.” With this loan, Auwalu will be able to access all the inputs and services to make these dreams reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Aliyu

texts.en: Aliyu is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Aliyu joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Sunusi, Abubakar, and  Hamisu,. Aliyu is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Aliyu will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Aliyu can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Aliyu is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “make more money for myself and my family”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Mekar Jadi Pondoan Group

texts.en:
As the agreement, the Mekar Jadi Pondoan group made their payments. With 5 members, they made the payment together of 12,500,000 IDR. During the loan period, they managed the pigs well. With the instructions from their vet, the group kept the pigs by giving them nutritious feed and vitamins. Ni Nyoman sold her 3 piglets and earned nett profit of 1,500,000 IDR. It’s all after deducting the cost of feed and making her payment. She’s really happy for that and decided to continue her loan to increase the population of her pigs. All the profit was used for her family's daily needs and school fees.

Mekar Jadi Pondoan group now gets their fifth loan from MUK. They have two new members who joined the group. With 7 members, the total loan is 17,500,000 IDR. The loan will be used to buy piglets and repair cages. Ni Nyoman, as the head of the group, is using the loan to buy two superior piglets and also feed. The price for superior pig species is currently very expensive, ranging from 500,000 - 600,000 IDR. These pigs will be maintained for 5 months for fattening. Ni Nyoman expects during the loan period the pig will be able to develop properly, without being attacked by disease. With this effort, she has a dream to fix her house.

loans.use: to buy two superior piglets and feed.

loans.name: Melida

texts.es:
La señora Melida es una persona muy trabajadora y responsable vive en una comunidad al sur de Honduras junto a su familia. Su negocio es la venta de golosinas y condimentos, desde hace 15 años.
Doña Melida su negocio funciona en su casa de habitación en el municipio donde vive y necesita el préstamo para la compra de arroz, frijoles, azúcar, manteca, café, agua, plátanos, refrescos, etc. y así aumentar la producción su negocio y de esta manera seguir preparando sus golosinas de las cuales sus ventas le ayudan mucho ya que las ganancias son de mucha utilidad en el hogar.
Doña Melida con el préstamo espera que sus ventas aumenten de forma considerablemente y así satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes,  gracias a esto espera poder mejorar la calidad de vida de la familia con el aumento de los ingresos en el hogar.
Uno de sus sueños es que en un corto plazo hacer crecer su negocio y  con esto poder seguir apoyando a su familia y que sus hijos tengan los estudios necesarios, para que pueda tener mayores oportunidades en la vida.


Choluteca, Honduras – Julio  del  2014
texts.en:
Melida is a very hardworking and responsible person who lives in a community in the south of Honduras with her family. She has run a business selling sweets and condiments for 15 years.   

Melida runs her business from her home in the municipality where she lives. She needs a loan to buy rice, beans, sugar, butter, coffee, water, bananas, soft drinks, etc. to increase her business's turnover and continue preparing her sweets. This will improve her sales which will be of great help to her since the income is put to much use in her home.

Melida hopes that with this loan her sales will increase considerably and she will be able to satisfy the demand of her customers. Thanks to this loan she hopes to improve the quality of life of her family as her income increase at home.

One of her short term dreams is to expand her business so that she can continue supporting her family and her children to obtain the education they need to have better opportunities in life.

Choluteca, Honduras – July 2014

loans.use: to buy rice, beans, sugar, butter, coffee, water, bananas, soft drinks, etc. for her business

loans.name: Kitchellyn

texts.en:
Kitchellyn has started her photo printing business in Sindangan. Her chosen business is not as difficult as she would think since she always has the practical experience in doing photography and artistry. She would also accept layout and art designs for marketing materials.

Kitchellyn saw the potential demand and growth of her business, which gave her the steps to approach Paglaum for the needed capital. She applied for a loan to purchase photo paper and ink refills. She is confident of gaining more profit with enough supplies available for printing. In the near future, she hopes to open a bigger photo shop and would love to invest more on different licensed photo software.

loans.use: to purchase photo paper and ink refills

loans.name: Nobelinda

texts.en:
Nobelinda is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business buying and selling meat in the Philippines.

She is borrowing PHP 14,000 through NWTF to purchase additional kilos of meat to sell for her business buying and selling meat.

Nobelinda has been in this business for one year. She earns more income from selling vegetables.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional kilos of meat to sell

loans.name: Kristyl

texts.en:
As a single parent of her children, Kristyl works hard to support her family.

She has a computer shop business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling Avon products. Kristyl is borrowing PHP 28,000 through NWTF to buy additional computer units for her computer shop business.

Kristyl has been sustaining her business activities through her past 9 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her to attain her dream of building and expanding her business to secure her family's future.

loans.use: to buy additional computer units for her business

loans.name: Sinuanua

texts.en:
Sinuanua is 59 years old and married with seven children.

She has a small plantation where she grows taro and bananas that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for four years. Sinuanua needs a loan to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gum boots and a spade.

She has been a member of SPBD since 2010. She will use the profits from her sales to pay for her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gum boots and a spade

loans.name: Maria Fe

texts.en: Maria Fe started a hobby of garden-plotting right at her own backyard. Later she realized to make money out of her agricultural skills. She plants a variety of vegetables. She signed up her membership with Paglaum MPC to access financial help. Recently, she applied for a loan to buy compost and fertilizers. Someday, Maria Fe hopes to buy farm land to start corn and rice farming.

loans.use: to buy compost and fertilizers.

loans.name: 1 De Marzo Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se llama 1 de Marzo, ellas se unieron con el propósito de poder ayudarse por medio del esfuerzo en conjunto para que por medio de ello sus familias vayan creciendo y mejorando.
Ilda es una de las integrantes de este grupo, ella se dedica a la venta de todo tipo de productos en su copetín, el cual pudo montar con mucho sacrificio. Ilda empieza su día de trabajo todos los días desde muy tempranas horas, hasta muy tarde en la noche, es una mujer muy sacrificada y luchadora.
Pide este préstamo la señora Ilda para poder comprar insumos varios para la venta en su copetín, como ser jugos, gaseosas, comestibles, golosinas y demás productos. Esta agradecida por la oportunidad que está recibiendo de poder seguir creciendo.
texts.en:
The group called “1 de Marzo” (March 1st) was formed so that the members could make a concerted effort to help one another in order for their families to grow and improve.

Ilda is one of the members of this group. She sells all types of products at her snack bar that she started with great sacrifice. Ilda begins every work day in the early morning hours and continues late into the evening. She is a self-sacrificing and determined woman.

Ilda is requesting a loan so that she can buy various products to sell at her snack bar such as juices, sodas, snack foods, candies, and other items. She is grateful for the opportunity she has received to keep growing.

loans.use: to buy juices, sodas, snack foods, candies, and other items to sell at her snack bar.

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en: Estrella has a small time backyard garden in Sindangan. She grows a variety of crops and has a promising income of PHP 6,000 per month. For this cropping season, she availed herself of a loan to buy seedlings and fertilizer. She hopes to double her produce so she can support the needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy seedlings and fertilizer

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie is 39 years old and married with three children, two of whom are in school.

Melanie works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more items like biscuits, soft drinks and bread.

Melanie has borrowed and paid back four loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 17 years and also earns an income from clothing sales.

Melanie aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more items like biscuits, soft drinks and bread.

loans.name: Analeah

texts.en:
Analeah is 36 years old and married with six children.

She earns a living by pig fattening in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 21,000 through NWTF to purchase additional feed and rice bran.

Analeah has been pig fattening for six years and also earns additional income from buying and selling charcoal.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and now she has requested an additional loan to further build her business.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional feed and rice bran

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
As a married mother of three children, Marlyn works hard to support her family.

She has a personal product retail business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from fattening pig. Marlyn is borrowing PHP 13,000 through NWTF in order to buy more items like perfume, body lotion and ready-to-wear clothing.

Marlyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more items like perfume, body lotion and ready-to-wear clothing.

loans.name: Anabelle

texts.en:
Anabelle works hard to support her family. She is married and has a food vending business in the Philippines.

Anabelle requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to purchase ingredients for her food production business. She has been in this business for 19 years now.

Anabelle would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna is 57 years old and married with seven children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 14,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc.

Myrna has borrowed and paid back six loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for six years and also earns an income from pig fattening.

She aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy farm supplies for her coffee crop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy doors for her house, as well as cement, sand, and gravel, and hire labor to put up drywall.

loans.name: Esperanza Y Progreso De Huaycan Group

texts.es: La Alcancía Comunal “Esperanza y Progreso De Huaycán”  está conformado 07 socios solidarios. Celsa de 45 años de edad separada con 01 hijo dependiente. Ella se dedica a la venta de pollos en un puesto de mercado.  Hace más de 23 años que inicio su negocio lo cual le ha ido bien. El crédito que solicitó lo destinará para la compra de una balanza electrónica que es su herramienta de trabajo diario. Su mayor anhelo es contar con otro puesto de venta en un mercado similar. El grupo  “Esperanza y Progreso De Huaycán” agradecen a los inversionistas Kiva por el crédito brindado. Celsa es la tercera del lado izquierdo y lleva en brazo a su bebe.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Esperanza y Progreso de Huaycán" consists of seven members.  Celsa, 45, is divorced and has a son in her care.  She sells chickens at a stall in the market and started her business over 23 years ago.  It has been going well for her.

The loan she is requesting is to buy an electronic scale to use as a work tool on a daily basis.  Her greatest desire is to have another stall at the market.  

The "Esperanza y Progreso de Huaycán" group is grateful to Kiva lenders for the loan.  Celsa is third from the left holding her son.

loans.use: To buy an electronic scale which will be her daily working tool.

loans.name: Allan Ramon

texts.es:
El señor Allan de 44  años de edad es soltero vive  en su casa de habitación, en la comunidad de San Lorenzo, valle  en la zona sur de Honduras, se dedica desde 05  años al negocio de venta de producto de reciclaje que son botes de refrescos de todos los tamaños.

Don Allan sus ventas son a una fábrica de reciclaje ubicada en la parte norte del país, es un hombre trabajador con deseos de salir adelante, está solicitando el préstamo para comprar 10,000 libras de plástico,  con el apoyo del crédito el desea colocar mas producto en la fabrica en donde vende el producto ya que tiene  un buen pedido y desea aprovechar en esta ocasión para obtener más ganancias y emplear más personas que recolectan este producto.

Don Allan  es un cliente nuevo y su sueño es mejorar su vehículo.


San Lorenzo. Honduras - Julio del 2014
texts.en:
Allan, 44, is single and lives in a house in the community of San Lorenzo, a valley in southern Honduras.  For five years he has been selling recycled materials such as soft drink cans in various sizes.

He sells to a recycling plant in the northern part of the country.  He is a hard-working man with a desire to get ahead.  The loan he is requesting is to buy 10,000 lbs. of plastic.  With the help of the loan he hopes to sell more products to the plant because he has received a large order.  He wants to take advantage of the situation to earn more and employ more people to collect this product.

Allan is a new client and wants to renovate his vehicle.


San Lorenzo, Honduras - July, 2014

loans.use: To buy plastic for his business.

loans.name: Lema

texts.en:
Lema is 40 years old and is unmarried with four children.
 
She has a small plantation where she grows taro and bananas that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for four years. Lema needs a loan to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gumboots and a spade. 

Lema has been a member of SPBD since 2010. She will use the profits from her sales to pay for her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gumboots and a spade.

loans.name: Sari Indah Badung Group

texts.en:
Ni Nyoman bought two superior piglets and feed with her loans. Before the repayment date, she sold all of her pigs and earned a satisfactory profit. She is really happy for that, because during the period, her pigs grew well, free from diseases, and she could sell them for a high price. The profits can help fulfil their daily life, the education of her children, and support the capital for her bussines. Now she can make her dream come true to renovate her kitchen. 

Ni Nyoman is very grateful to MUK, KIVA and lenders for supporting her bussines. She said she will always need assistance from the loan officer of MUK to give advice and solutions for the business.

To increase their businesses, the Sari Indah Badung group continues to borrow from MUK. They feel comfortable to have the loan, because they have also been trained by the MUK staff.
 
After the success of the last loan, Ni Nyoman will again use her loan to purchase superior piglets for fattening into pigs. Currently the price for one superior piglet is Rp.500.000.  Ni Nyoman will use all of the profits from this business to support her children's education. She hopes the business will grow and she will become a successful pig breeder.

loans.use: to buy superior piglets.

loans.name: Jonave

texts.en:
Jonave is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for four years, and earns more income from buying and selling fish. 

She is borrowing PHP 29,000 through NWTF to buy items like shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell in her general store business.

Jonave successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested an additional loan to further build her business. She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy items like shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Saofai

texts.en:
Saofai is a 58-year-old married woman with nine children. She runs a small fishing business in her community to earn a living. She has five years of experience with this business. 

Saofai needs a loan to buy a new fishing canoe, a large cooler, a chest freezer, hooks, bait, flippers and new goggles. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. Saofai has been a member of SPBD since 2009.

loans.use: to buy a new fishing canoe, a large cooler, a chest freezer, hooks, bait, flippers and new goggles

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is 57 years old, and is married with six children, one of whom is in school.

Helen has an agricultural business, growing rice in the Philippines. She has been growing rice for six years now, and has borrowed twenty-two times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

She has requested a PHP 23,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

In the future, Helen would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Maria works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from fattening pigs.  Maria is borrowing PHP 22,000 through NWTF to buy fishing materials for her fishing business.

Maria has been sustaining her business activities through her past nine loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials for her business.

loans.name: Repeka

texts.en:
Repeka is 39 years old and is married with five children. She has a small plantation where she grows taro and bananas that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for four years. 

Repeka needs a loan to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gumboots and crops. She has been a member of SPBD since 2010. Repeka will use the profits from her sales to pay for her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, fertilizer, a new wheelbarrow, a tiller, a rake, new gumboots and crops.

loans.name: Po

texts.en:
Po is a 35-year-old unmarried woman with eight children. She runs a small fishing business in her community to earn a living. She has five years of experience with this business. 

Po needs a loan to buy a new fishing canoe, a large cooler, a chest freezer, hooks, bait, flippers and new goggles. She plans to use her profits to pay for her family's weekly expenses. Po has been a member of SPBD since 2009.

loans.use: to buy a new fishing canoe, a large cooler, a chest freezer, hooks, bait, flippers and new goggles.

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon is a 57-year-old married woman with two children, one of whom is still in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Corazon has a business selling rice in the Philippines. She has been in this business for two years. She has requested a loan of PHP 19,000 through NWTF to purchase more sacks of rice to sell.

In the future, Corazon would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more sacks of rice to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy doors and windows for her home as well as paying for cement, sand and labourers to whitewash the walls.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy wood, metal sheets, nails and bolts to repair the roof of her home

loans.name: Mawar Group

texts.en:
The Mawar Group has been through several loans cycles, and the group has repaid their previous loans on time. They are still involved in fattening pigs and pig barbeque programs. They enjoy borrowing a loan from MUK, because they are in a group, get trained, and the loan does not need any collateral from the borrower. However, they are very responsible for the loan.

Ni Komang, the head of the group, sold her three pigs after managing them for five months. She was really happy with the result. The profits were used to make repayments and also for saving.

Ni Komang and the members of Mawar group are really thankful because they are still trusted to receive loans. The ten members all get the same loan amount.

Now Ni Komang has a sow. She will use the loan to purchase superior feed and renovate the cage. She hopes the piglets can grow fast and she plans to sell them after two months.

One member couldn't attend the meeting because she just had a baby and is staying at home.

loans.use: to purchase superior feed and renovate the cage for her pigs.

loans.name: Alma Yudith

texts.es:
La señora Alma Judith de 33 años de edad,  es madre soltera, tiene una  hija que depende de ella, vive en casa propia en una comunidad  de Nacaome, valle al sur de Honduras.
Doña Alma se dedica desde hace 21  años  al negocio de la elaboración golosinas, es una mujer trabajadora que lucha todos los días por sacar adelante a su hija.
Doña Alma está solicitando el préstamo para la compra de plátanos, frijoles, pollo, aceite, harina, etc. para elaborar sus golosinas,  con el apoyo de este préstamo espera  mejorar sus ingresos y por ende su calidad de vida.
Su sueño es mejorar su negocio y su calidad de vida y también ampliar su casa está muy contenta por el apoyo de Prisma a su negocio porque estos préstamos le han ayudado a salir adelante.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - Julio del 2014.
texts.en:
Señora Alma Judith is 33 years old. She has a daughter who depends on her, and she lives in her own home in a community in Nacaome, a valley in the south of Honduras.

Doña Alma has worked making treats since she was 21. She is a hard-working woman who struggles daily to help her daughter get ahead.

Doña Alma is asking for this loan in order to buy bananas, beans, chicken, oil, flour to make her products. With the support of this loan she hopes to increase her income, and in consequence her quality of life.

Her dream is to improve her business and her quality of life and also expand her home. She is very happy to have the support of Prisma for her business because the loans have helped her to get ahead.

San Lorenzo, Honduras - July 2014.

loans.use: to buy bananas, beans, chicken, oil, flour etc. for her business.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 64 years old and is married with one child. Elizabeth works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy more groceries to sell in her store.

Elizabeth has borrowed and repaid 15 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for three years and also earns an income from pig fattening.

Elizabeth aspires to save money to expand her business and repair her family's home.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell in her store.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en: Daniel remembers feeling depressed  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Daniel, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Daniel  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community” expressed Daniel.   With this loan, Daniel is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Roselieta

texts.en:
Roselieta found a better location for her motorcycle parts business in Sindangan. Roselieta has secured her inventory of parts and made good monitoring on her greatest demands. Now, she wants to increase her stock by adding more inventory to resell. She has calculated the funds needed and approached PMPC for these. She hopes to obtain more income with enough inventory and not miss business opportunities.
 
In the future, Roselieta dreams of opening her own motorcycle showroom.

loans.use: to buy motorcycle parts to resell.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 63 years old and is married with three children. 

Erlinda is in the agricultural business, raising livestock in the Philippines. She has been raising livestock for 15 years now, and has borrowed 21 times in the past from NWTF to sustain her activities. Erlinda has now requested a PHP 23,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional livestock, feed and other supplies for her business.

Erlinda would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional livestock, feed and other supplies for her business.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Pedro Pablo

texts.es:
Pedro tiene 58 años de edad vive en el cantón San Miguel Provincia de Bolivar su estado civil es casado vive con su esposa. 
Es integrante de la ventanilla rural Ambrocio Laso que se dedica a las labores agricolas.

Pedro se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de papa, mellocos y habas  también a la crianza de pollo de canchón utilizara el dinero del crédito para la compra de animales para criarles y engordarles, con el apoyo del crédito incrementar su negocio, el realiza las compras  de insumos y alimentos en Chimbo.
  Las metas y sueños que él tiene son tener un carro para llevar a vender lo que cosecha y los animales el enfrentara los desafíos que se le presenten en la vida en su tiempo libre se dedica al deporte.
texts.en:
Pedro is 58 years old and lives in the canton of San Miguel in the Bolivar province. He is married and lives with his wife. He is a member of the rural solidarity group Ambrocio Laso which is dedicated to agricultural activities.

Pedro works as a farmer sowing potatoes, ullucos and beans as well as raising chickens and pigs. He will use the money from this loan to purchase animals to raise and fatten up. With the support of this loan he will expand his business by purchasing supplies and feed in Chimbo.

Pedro's goals and dreams are to have a car with which to transport and sell his harvested crops and animals. He will meet any challenge that presents itself in his life. In his free time Pedro likes to play sport.

loans.use: to buy animals to raise

The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Usaini  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community” expressed Usaini.   With this loan, Usaini is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

However, Ibrahim  is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season because this loan will give him access to high quality inputs such as unadulterated Urea.  “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community” expressed Ibrahim. With this loan, Ibrahim is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Sheryl

texts.en:
Sheryl is 27 years old and is married with two children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell, such as canned goods, eggs, milk, sugar, etc.

Sheryl has borrowed and repaid eight loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for two years and also earns an income from selling rice.

She aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell, such as canned goods, eggs, milk, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie is 35 years old and is married with two children.

Elvie works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy more groceries to sell.

She has borrowed and repaid three loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for five years and also earns an income from e-loading (mobile prepaid loading).

Elvie aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Rene Hilario

texts.es:
René es un veterano con mucha experiencia en el campo. Es humilde y sencillo, tiene un gran don de gente y energía suficiente para poder cualquier cultivo a producir.

El posee un cultivo de Café en el municipio de Caicedo, Antioquia que asiste todos los días sin falta; gracias a sus 10 años de experiencia en esta materia, tiene plena capacidad para trabajar y para asesorar en estos temas.

Pide el apoyo de un crédito para comprar insumos agrícolas como abonos y riegos, de esta manera podrá inyectar capital a su actividad y podrá tener unos mucho más fértiles.
Tiene mucha fe en su negocio y grandes esperanzas en las personas solidarias.
Su mayor motivación son su esposa y sus hijos a los cuales desea sacarlos adelante.
texts.en:
René is a veterinarian with a lot of experience in the field. He is a humble and unassuming man with a lot of charisma and enough energy to enable anything to grow.  

René has a coffee crop in the municipality of Caicedo, Antioquia, where he goes every day without fail. Thanks to his 10 years of experience in this field, he is fully able to work the land and give advice about these matters. 

René has applied for a loan to purchase agricultural supplies such as fertilisers and irrigation so that he can inject capital into his work and have much more fertile land.

René has a lot of faith in his business and great hope in the people who support him. His greatest motivation is his wife and children who he hopes will get ahead in life.

loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies

loans.name: Yakubu

texts.en: Yakubu is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Yakubu joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children: Musa, Iliya, and  Manaseh. Yakubu is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Yakubu will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Yakubu can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Yakubu is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his long-term goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Cleofe

texts.es:
La socia Cleofe  se dedica al negocio de venta de frutas , la socia lleva a diferentes lugares, la socia vende platanos, naranjas y manzanas , la socia ya tiene varios años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es tener un local donde pueda vender las frutas . La socia solicita el crédito para comprar naranjas, plátanos y uvas . 

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Cleofe runs a business selling fruit which she sells in different areas. She has sold bananas, oranges and apples for many years and it has gone very well for her. 

Cleofe's dream is to have a store where she can sell her fruit. She is applying for a loan to buy oranges, bananas and grapes.

Cleofe is happy to have this loan and she promises to make all her repayments on time.

loans.use: to buy oranges, bananas and grapes

loans.name: Markus Mai'unguwa

texts.en: Markus Mai'unguwa remembers not being able to feed his family  during a particularly bad harvest. This is before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, as a Babban Gona member, Markus Mai'unguwa like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the National average of 14. However, Markus Mai'unguwa,  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 70 bags per hectare this season largely due to the improved seeds that he will access with this loan. When asked about his future plans,  Markus Mai'unguwa said: “In 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, Markus Mai'unguwa is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Juan Francisco

texts.es: Juan de 46 años de edad vive con su esposa y sus 2 hijos una niña de 12 años y un varón de 15 años de edad. Él es un hombre trabajador que además de prestar sus servicios de seguridad es agricultor, su esposa aporta a la economía familiar prestando sus servicios domésticos de forma domiciliar. Juan desea instalar energía eléctrica en su vivienda por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para comprar un poste, los cables primarios y los de la instalación interna de su vivienda, además de interruptores y tubos para poder hacer la instalación lo antes posible
texts.en:
Juan is 46 years old and lives with his wife and two children: a 12 year old daughter and a 15 year old son. Juan is a hardworking man who, as well as running a security services business, also works as a farmer. His wife helps out with the home finances through her work as a cleaner in private homes. 

Juan would like to install electricity in his home, which is why he has applied for a credit from FUSAI. With this loan he will buy a pole, the main cables and other cables to install inside his home as well as the switches and tubing to connect the electricity as soon as possible.

loans.use: to buy a pole, the main cables and other cables to install inside his home as well as the switches and tubing to connect the electricity.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy materials to build a house.

loans.name: Juan Julian

texts.es:
Juan tiene 58 años de edad vive en el cantón San Miguel Provincia de Bolivar  su estado civil es casado vive con su esposa y su hijo de 18 años.
Es integrante de la ventanilla rural Ambrocio Laso que se dedican a las labores agricolas.
 
Juan se dedica a la agricultura y siembra de papas, mellocos y habas, también a la crianza de pollo de chanchón Utilizara el dinero del crédito para la compra de animales para criarles y engordarle para luego venderlos el apoyo del crédito incrementara el negocio.
El realiza las compras  de insumos y alimentos para los animales en Chimbo. Su sueños es tener un carro, se enfrentara a los desafíos que se le presenten en la vida, en su tiempo libre se dedica al deporte.
texts.en: Juan is 58 years old and lives in the district of San Miguel, in the province of Bolivar. He is married and lives with his spouse and their 18-year-old son. He belongs to rural communal bank Ambrocio Laso, the members of which are all farmers. Juan grows potatoes, ullucus, and beans, and rears chickens and pigs. He will use the loan to buy animals and fatten them to then resell them. This way, he will strengthen his business. He buys feed and all he needs to take care of the animals in Chimbo. He dreams of having a car, never backs down from the challenges life throws his way, and devotes his free time to sports.

loans.use: to buy animals to rear.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Maria Teresa

texts.es: Teresa de 47 años de edad vive con un hijo mayor de edad y 2 hijas de 14 y 15 años de edad. Ella es una mujer muy tenaz que se dedica a cultivar la tierra desde hace 16 años sembrando maíz y frijol.  Su hijo aporta con su trabajo de motorista, además otra hija y su esposo emigraron al extranjero para mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia. Teresa desea instalar energía eléctrica en su vivienda para lo que necesita comprar un poste y pagar instalación por lo que solicita a FUSAI un crédito para comprar poste de cemento, alambre, interruptores y pagar mano de obra para instalación de energía eléctrica en su vivienda.
texts.en: Teresa is 47 years old and lives with her son, who is an adult, and her two daughters, who are 14 and 15. She is someone who never gives up and has been a farmer for 16 years, growing sweetcorn and broad beans. Her son contributes to household expenses by working in transportation, and she has another daughter, who emigrated together with her husband to work abroad and send money back to the family. Teresa wants to have electricity in her house, which is why she needs to buy a concrete pole and face other expenses related to connecting to the network. She asks FUSAI for a loan in order to buy a concrete pole for electricity lines, wires, and switches, and to hire help to bring electricity to her house.

loans.use: to buy the necessary supplies and hire help to bring electricity to her house.

loans.name: Benkadi 2 Group

texts.fr:
Les 10 membres du groupe  BENKADI 2 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 41 ans, ont en moyenne 6 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles traditionnelles à NIARADOUGOU un village dans la commune de DANDERESSO dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du MALI.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de campagne avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été correctement remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est de riz avec madame NASSARATA débout à la première position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe de femme BENKADI 2. 
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter 2 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 1 bidon d’herbicide, payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  0, 5 hectare. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO  à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant et à crédit.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 74 000 francs CFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et son intérêt, aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en: The 10 members of the Benkadi 2 Group are married women with an average age of 41. They have an average of 6 children and live for the most part in traditional families in the village of Niaradougou in the commune of Danderesso in the area of Sikasso, the third largest administrative region in Mali.  The women work with the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance organization to carry out their farming activities during the rainy season.  They are on their fifth loan; the previous loans were fully repaid.  Ms. Nassarata, the person standing at the very left of the photo, grows rice. With her loan, she plans to buy two 50-kg bags of fertilizer, one container of herbicide, and to pay for the labor cost of maintaining .5 hectares of land.  After the harvest, the output will be sold at the village level in Sikasso to a clientele of men and women, for cash and credit.  She plans to earn an average profit of 74,000 FCFA per season.  This profit will enable her to repay her loan and the interest, as well as help her husband with the daily expenses of their family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, herbicide, and to pay for labor costs.

In the future, she wants to find a better job with a higher salary and have her own house.

Maria has been a member of SPBD since 2011.

loans.use: to buy sandwiches, pies, donuts, snacks, coffee, a large boiler and soft drinks.

texts.en:
Jorgia finds comfort in raising pigs right in her backyard. She earns a promising income every month doing this type of work. Jorgia obtained her initial capital to purchase her original piglets and feed. 

Now, she requests a loan of 18,000 PHP to buy feeds and vitamins. She really hopes and prays that her business will grow and benefit her family. Someday, she wants to build a concrete pig cage to easily keep more sanitary conditions.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins.

loans.name: Cecil Grace

texts.en:
Hardworking mother best describes Cecil Grace, 29 years old, residing in the Basac Siquior. Cecil Grace has one child and is married to a private employee.  The wage that her husband gets is not enough to cover their daily needs. So, Cecil Grace started a business, a food stand or “carenderia.” Cecil Grace has been in the business for more than a year now. 

Cecil Grace wants to expand her food stand business .  She wants to earn more profit and to have enough to sustain her family, especially her children, and she would be able to send her son to college. In order for  Cecil Grace to make her wish possible, she needs PHP 5,000 as additional capital and will use the money to expand her business.  She intends to buy meat and other ingredients needed in the food stand. She hopes to live a comfortable life someday with her family.

loans.use: to buy meat and other ingredients

Marissa Kylle sells snacks to earn a living and has had this business for four years. She has requested a loan to buy needed ingredients for her snack vending business.

Marissa Kylle has been a member of PMPC for a month. In the future, Marissa Kylle hopes to promote her finished products and expand her business.

loans.name: Mateo David

texts.es:
Mateo tiene 23 años de edad vive en el cantón San Miguel Provincia de Bolivar su estado civil es casado vive con su esposa y sus dos hijos de 3 y 1 año.
Es integrante de la ventanilla rural Ambrocio Laso que se dedican a las labores agricolas.
 
Mateo se dedica a la agricultura, a la crianza de pollo de canchón utilizara el dinero del crédito para comprar animales para luego vfenderlos, con el apoyo del crédito incrementara su negocio, el realiza las compras de los balanceados para los animales en Chimbo.
Su sueño es estar siempre feliz con su familia, los desafios a los que se enfrenta es la competencia, en el tiempo lire le gusta jugar boli.
texts.en:
Mateo is 23 years old and lives in the Canton of San Miguel in the province of Bolivar. He is married and lives with his wife and their two children, ages 3 and 1. He is a member of the communal bank Ambrocio Laso which is focussed on agricultural work.

Mateo makes a living in agriculture, raising chickens in enclosed fields. He will use the loan money to buy animals in order to sell them later. With the help of the loan, he will increase his business. He buys the feed for his animals in Chimbo. His dream is to always be happy with his family. The challenge he faces is competition. In his free time he likes to play volleyball.

loans.use: to buy animals to raise.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy bricks, sand, gravel and cement for the wall, metal sheets, wood and nails for the roof, and wire, switches and tubes for the electrical installation.

loans.name: Jose Esteban

texts.es: Esteban de 28 años de edad vive con su compañera de vida y su hija de 8 años de edad. Él es un hombre muy trabajador que se gana la vida de diferentes formas es agricultor cultiva maíz y maicillo, por las tardes es ayudante en uncamion y en las mañanas es jornalero. Esteban desea terminar de construir su vivienda pues como se puede observar en la fotografía solo tiene las paredes por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para comprar lámina, madera y barillas de hierro  para poner el techo, cemento y arena para repellar las paredes y comprar puertas y ventanas para la seguridad de su familia y sus pertenencias.
texts.en:
Esteban is 28 years old and lives with his partner and 8-year-old daughter. He is a very hard-working man who makes a living in various different ways. He works as a farmer growing corn and sorghum. In the afternoons, he is a helper in a truck, and in the mornings, he is a labourer.

Esteban wants to finish building his home because as you can see in the photo, only the walls are complete. This is why he is requesting a loan from FUSAI to buy sheeting, wood and bars to build a roof, cement and sand to plaster, and doors and windows to make his family and his belongings safe.

loans.use: to buy sheeting, wood and bars to build a roof, cement and sand to plaster, and doors and windows for his home.

loans.name: Paula Mercedes

texts.es: Paula de 23 años de edad vive con su compañero de vida y sus 2 hijos uno de 7 años que estudia y uno de 2 meses de edad. Paula es una mujer luchadora que se dedica a la venta de fruta partida en el centro de su municipio, además su compañero de vida trabaja como panificador lo que les permite tener un ingreso más en la economía familiar. Paula desea reparar las paredes de su vivienda y construir un patio techado por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para comprar cemento, arena, ladrillo, grava, lámina, madera y pagar mano de obra para la mejora y la construcción.
texts.en:
Paula is 23 years old and lives with her partner and her 2 children. One is 7 years old and goes to school, and one is 2 months old. Paula is a hard-working woman who makes a living selling fruit in the centre of her town. Her partner works as a baker, which enables them to have two wages to put towards the family income. 

Paula wants to repair the walls of her home and build a covered patio, which is why she is requesting a loan from FUSAI to buy cement, sand, bricks, gravel,  sheeting and wood, and pay for workmen to make the improvements and do the building work.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand, gravel and bricks to build a patio and improve the walls, and sheeting and wood for the roof of her home.

loans.name: Bulus Hassan

texts.en: Bulus Hassan remembers not being able to provide enough food for his family during a particularly bad harvest. This is before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, as a Babban Gona member, Bulus Hassan, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the National average of 14. However, Bulus Hassan is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 per hectare this season.  Bulus Hassan expressed that “In 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, Bulus Hassan is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Philibus

texts.en: Philibus is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Philibus joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his  children, Justina and Jenifa. Philibus is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Philibus will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Philibus can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money to expand my farmland.” Philibus is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his long term goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy bricks, cement, sand, gravel, sheeting and wood to build a room for the kitchen and the patio of his home.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cement, sand, gravel, sheet metal, wood and nails to change the roof, cement the floor, and paint the walls of her house.

loans.name: Yosef Sadewo

texts.en:
Yosef is a prospective student at Academy of Maritime Nusantara (AMN) of the faculty of commerce and harbor administration. Yosef lives in the interior of Borneo, which is located far from the city, precisely in Tanjung Selor, East Kalimantan. Yosef recently graduated from high school and wants to continue his studies in AMN. 

Yosef's father works as a motorcycle taxi driver with a motorcycle in the city, and his mother had died some time ago. Yosef was the first child of three siblings; his father must now take care of them without a mother. 

Because his father's income is minimal, Yosef is unable to continue his studies and is concerned. With these conditions, Yosef did not want to bother his father because their income is uncertain. Yosef wants to get a loan from Kiva to help pay for college later so that he can finish his studies and get a job quickly, and can help his sisters to attend school, according to his father's expectations.

loans.use: to pay his education fees for three years.

loans.name: Sa'ade

texts.en: Sa'ade is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Sa'ade joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her children Zainab,Hassan,and Usaina. Sa'ade is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Sa'ade will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, she would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Sa'ade can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and earn up to $2,000 per ha, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. When asked how she plans to spend the income she will make this year as a Babban Gona member, she said, “I plan to use the money to expand my farmland.” Sa'ade is not thinking about this year alone; she expressed that her longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Leatu

texts.en: Leatu remembers not being able to pay her children's school fees as a result of a particularly bad harvest. This was before she became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Leatu, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Leatu  is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season because this loan will give her access to high quality inputs such as quality fertilizer.  “In 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family” expressed Leatu. With this loan, Leatu is well on her way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Samson

texts.en: Samson remembers not being able to feed his family  during a particularly bad harvest. This is before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, as a Babban Gona member, Samson like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the National average of 14. However, Samson,  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  Samson expressed that “In 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs.” With this loan, Samson is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Mexlin

texts.en:
Mexlin just graduated from high school and wants to continue his studies in AMN. Currently, Mexlin is a prospective student at Academy of Maritime Nusantara (AMN). He wants to study marine engineering. 

Mexlin lives in a rural coastal area, in Central Tapanuli, Sumatra Island. He expects to complete the program of study, but he has concerns about the cost of his studies. Mexlin’s parents works as farmers, with minimal income, so there is difficulty to finance his studies. Mexlin is the third child of seven siblings, and there are four siblings who have a lot of costs to complete their schooling. 

Mexlin wishes to be able to work on a ship as a technician professional because he has had this dream since early childhood. However, he understands the economic condition of his parents because the parents have to pay for their schooling. Mexlin is eager to get a loan from Kiva to help pay for college later so that he could complete his studies, get a job quickly and can help his younger siblings achieve their dreams.

loans.use: to pay his education fees for three years.

loans.name: John Fisher Ike Geroda

texts.en:
Being a ship’s officer is the ideal for John. A prospective student at Academy of Maritime Nusantara, he will take courses in nautical science. 

John has two siblings, and his father works just as a regular employee, with minimal income, while his mother does not have special skills, so she does not work. John had given up hope with the family’s economic conditions. His brother is not willing to continue school because of the condition of the family economy.

John wants to continue his education because he did not want to study to high school only. John is very grateful to God, even though he lives simply, but God touched the whole family’s life. John was very grateful for the participation of Kiva loans that have been given, thus providing impetus for John to be more diligent and work harder to learn.

loans.use: to pay his education fees for three years.

loans.name: Iliya Lado

texts.en: Iliya Lado remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This is before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, as a Babban Gona member, Iliya Lado like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the National average of 14. However, Iliya Lado,  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season. Iliya Lado expressed that “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, Iliya Lado is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Yakubu

texts.en: Yakubu remembers not being able to feed his family during a particularly bad harvest. This is before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, as a Babban Gona member, Yakubu like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the National average of 14. Yakubu is ambitious with plans to reap yields higher than both the national and Babban Gona averages. Yakubu expressed that “In 5 years, I want to ensure my children Mustafa and Mairabare are educated and have professional jobs.” With this loan, Yakubu is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to recharge her vaults for money transfers.

loans.name: Isabela

texts.es:
En el departamento de Sololá, durante 10 años, Isabel, mujer casada de 21 años, se ha dedicado a la agricultura. Como mujer trabajadora, ha tomado el reto de cultivar terrenos en donde nadie se ha atrevido a hacerlo.
Detrás de ella, la apoya una familia formada por su esposo que se dedica como guardián en una finca, y sus hijos varones de 15, 17, 10 años donde los mayores también se dedican a laborar en otros trabajos.  Además de dos preciosas hijas de 11 y 13 años en edad de estudios primarios.
La actividad agrícola que ella realiza necesita de insumos, razón por la cual solicita un préstamo para comprarlo y así seguir adelante y darles un ejemplo de trabajo y manutención a sus hijos que aún están estudiando.
texts.en: In the Department of Sololá, for the last ten years, Isabel, a woman married for 21 years, has made a living in agriculture. As a hardworking woman, she took on the challenge of cultivating land where no one had dared to do it. She is supported by a family made up of her husband, who works as groundskeeper for a farm, and her sons of 15, 17 and 10 years of age, the older ones who also work other jobs. She also has two beautiful daughters,11 and 13 years old, who are in their primary education. The agricultural activity that she does requires supplies. For this reason she is requesting a loan to buy the supplies and in that way make progress and give her children who are still at school a good example of work and maintenance.

loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies.

loans.name: Mkananda Group

texts.en:
MWAJUMA, who is in her mid 30s, is married with four children who are still in school. She has been running a fruits and vegetables business for three years now. She works from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.  

This will be MWAJUMA's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She will use this loan to buy fruits and vegetables to meet her customers' demands. She dreams of owning a beauty salon.

MWAJUMA will share this loan with her loan group, "MKANANDA," which has 10 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Sinignessigui 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les 9 membres du groupe  SINIGNESSIGUI 1 sont des hommes mariés  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 43 ans et ont en moyenne 7 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des  familles traditionnelles à NIARADOUGOU un village dans la commune de DANDERESSO dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Ils  collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils sont à leur cinquième prêt de production de maïs avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est de maïs  avec monsieur DIAKALIA débout à la première position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe d’homme SINIGNESSIGUI 1 . 
Avec son prêt, il compte acheter 14 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 20 bidons d’herbicide de qualité différente, payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir  3,5 hectares. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  520 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part de contribuer  les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The 9 members of the Sinignessigui 1 group are married men with an average age of 43 years and an average of 7 children each. They mostly live in traditional families in Niaradougou, a village in the Danderesso community in Sikasso, the third administrative region of Mali.

The men have partnered with the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso in order to better manage their farming businesses during the rainy season. They are on their 5th group loan with the organization, with their previous loans having been fully repaid. 

Diakalia, pictured as the first man standing from left to right in the photo, is a member of the Sinignessigui 1 group who is in the business of cultivating corn. With his loan, Diakalia plans to purchase 14 bags of 50kg of fertilizer, 20 barrels of herbicide of various types, and to pay the labor costs to maintain 3.5 hectares.

After his harvest, Diakalia sells his crops in the villages of Sikasso to a customer base made up of both men and women, for both cash and credit. He hopes to earn an average income of 520,000 francs CFA per crop. This income will allow Diakalia to pay back the loan and interest as well as to contribute to the daily expenses for his family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and pay labor costs

loans.name: Sitha

texts.en: Sitha is 25 years old and a student at a university. He lives in Takeo Province, Cambodia. Due to the lack of financial support, he would like to request a loan to pay for his tuition fee. This loan will help him graduate. In the future, he is going to find a good job with a reasonable salary to help his family.

loans.use: to pay for his tuition fee

loans.name: Nadabo

texts.en: Nadabo is a 35-year-old farmer from Kwankwani. As a Babban Gona member, Nadabo, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Nadabo can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Nadabo is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to acces quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will result in a total yield of at least  100 bags this season. Nadabo is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children Firera, and Kabiru. Nadabo’s dreams do not end there; “Ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs” he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Desy Fitriani

texts.en:
Her goal to be a sailor has been Desy’s dream since childhood. She is currently a prospective student at the Academy of Maritime Nusantara. Nautical courses were selected by Desy. 

However, Desy has concerns that she cannot achieve these ideals due to economic factors hindering her family. Her father works as a construction worker, just an ordinary worker, and her mother did not have any special skills. Desy is the third child of five siblings, and her parents make every effort to help Desy achieve her desire and goal to be a reliable sailor.
