Through the student loan program of this Kiva loan, Desy hopes to complete college and quickly find a job on a cruise ship. She is very grateful to the investors of Kiva because, thanks to their help, she can cover the cost of tuition and can continue her studies. Desy also wants to help her younger siblings to continue their education.

loans.use: to pay her education fees for three years.

loans.name: Naomi I.

texts.en: Naomi I remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before she became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Naomi I, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Naomi I  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family” expressed Naomi I   With this loan, Naomi I is well on her way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Yusuf

texts.en: Yusuf is a 48-year- old farmer from Kuruntumawa. As a Babban Gona member, Yusuf, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Yusuf can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the National average of 14. However, Yusuf is ambitious and is aiming to reap 38 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Yusuf said “I plan to use the money I make to educate my children; Alhamdu, Lidiya, and Rahab,and in 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs.” With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Nishemiya

texts.en: Nishemiya remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This is before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, as a Babban Gona member, Nishemiya like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the National average of 14. However, Nishemiya,  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season.  Nishemiya expressed that “In 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, Nishemiya is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Gloria Esmeralda

texts.es: Gloria de 28 años de edad vive con su compañero de vida y sus dos hijos de 3 y 8 años de edad, el mayor estudia. Ella es una mujer emprendedora que apoya a su esposo en la economía del hogar por medio de su pequeño negocio de venta de productos de primera necesidad que se encuentra ubicado en su vivienda, su compañero de vida se dedica a la elaboración de estructuras metálicas tales como: puertas, balcones, portones, etc. Gloria desea comprar los materiales para que su compañero de vida haga las puertas de su vivienda y se las coloque ya que como se observa en la fotografía solo cuentan con una cortina como puerta lo que provoca inseguridad a su familia por lo que necesitan poner las puertas lo antes posible, además desea encementar el patio por lo que solicita a FUSAI un crédito para comprar materiales para las puertas y cemento, arena y grava para el piso del patio.
texts.en: Gloria is 28 years old. She lives with her life's companion and their two children, aged 3 and 8. The oldest one is in school. She is an enterprising woman who helps her husband with the household budget through her small business selling staple products, It is located in her house. Her life's companion makes metallic structures such as doors, balconies, gates, etc. Gloria wants to buy the materials so he can make doors for their house, since as can be seen in the photograph, they only have a curtain for a door. This isn't secure for the family and they need to put on doors as soon as possible. She also wants to cement the floor of the patio and that is why she is asking FUSAI for a loan to buy materials for the doors and cement, sand and gravel for the patio floor.

loans.use: to buy materials for doors as well as cement, sand and gravel for the patio floor.

loans.name: Lenie

texts.en:
Lenie is aged 34 and married to a cellphone technician, and they're blessed with three children. She manages a direct selling business in which she sells personal use products and earns a net income of 2,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) monthly. Her net income on this business is usually spent on their daily expenses in their house. 

Due to insufficient funds, she would like to avail a loan amounting to PHP 13,000 to purchase talc powder, colognes, dresses, shoes and lotions to sell. She's hoping that her business will continue to improve and become more profitable.

loans.use: To purchase talc powder, colognes, dresses, shoes and lotions to sell.

loans.name: Sahabi

texts.en: Sahabi is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Sahabi joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his child, Firdausi. Sahabi is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Sahabi will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Sahabi can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Sahabi is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Marichelle

texts.en: Marichelle is 35-years-old, married and has a child. She is into a direct-selling business who sells AVON products such as colognes, body wash and powder to sell. She is now asking for a loan of PHP 4,000 to buy more colognes, perfumes and powder to sell. She would like to improve her income so she will save funds and make her business grow.

loans.use: to buy more colognes, perfumes and powder to sell

loans.name: Hilda

texts.en:
Hilda is 50 years old, married and had a child. She is managing a talipapa (food and vegetables stand), selling vegetables and meat products such as processed foods. 

She is now asking for a loan of 5,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) to increase her merchandise. She will buy more processed foods (hot dogs, cured pork). This will help her attain good sales and enable her to meet her customers' demand for the good and affordable goods she sells.

loans.use: to buy more processed foods (hot dogs, cured pork)

loans.name: Sumaira

texts.en:
Sumaira is a 30-year-old married woman. She runs a small, low-income private school. The school has an enrollment of around 89 children, over half of which are girls. She is able to use income from the school to contribute to the family income. Despite facing financial challenges because of competition from other schools in the community, she has provided needy children with free education along with free books and uniforms.

She is requesting a loan of 100,000 PKR (Pakistani rupees) which she wishes to use to purchase chairs and other furniture for the classrooms and to fix a problematic roof so that she can ensure a safe and comfortable school environment for her students.

loans.use: to purchase chairs and other furniture for the classrooms, and to fix a problematic roof.

loans.name: Glenda Licth

texts.es: Glenda gracias a su primer financiamiento logro dar una excelente asistencia y mantenimiento a sus cultivos de café encontrándose muy satisfecha y agradecida por el apoyo brindado por la cooperativa COMIXMUL en alianza con los diferentes inversionistas que el apoyaron en la plataforma de KIVA. Ella logro comprar urea, formula cafetalera, fórmula 18-26-0 y con otra parte pudo pagar la mano de obra calificada para dar asistencia a 2 manzanas de café cultivadas. Ella logro obtener una muy buena cosecha con la cual logro pagar su financiamiento con anticipación y debida diligencia. Nuevamente Glenda solicita un segundo financiamiento para seguir trabajando en la tecnificación de sus cultivos de café mediante la compra de más insumos como abono, fertilizantes, entre otros por lo que es una necesidad inmediata esperando ser nuevamente apoyada para ir cumpliendo poco a poco sus metas y sueños.
texts.en:
Thanks to her first loan, Glenda was able to give excellent help and maintenance to her coffee plants, and was very pleased with and grateful for the support she received from the cooperative COMIXMUL in alliance with the various lenders who helped her via Kiva. She was able to buy urea, coffee-growing formula, and formula 18-26-0, and was also able to pay for skilled labourers to look after two blocks of coffee plants. She managed to achieve a very good harvest with which she was able to repay her loan early and diligently. 

Glenda is now requesting a second loan to continue working to improve her coffee plants through buying more inputs such as compost, fertilisers, and other items. She needs them now, and is waiting to receive support again so that she can achieve her goals and dreams little by little.

loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs for her coffee plants.

loans.name: Sokhea

texts.en: Sokhea is 20 years old and a student at an institute. He lives in Prey Veng Province, Cambodia. Due to the lack of financial support, he would like to request a loan to pay for his tuition fee. This loan will help him graduate. In the future, he is going to find a good job with a reasonable salary to help his family and build a new house.

loans.use: to pay for his tuition fee

loans.name: Mujeres Positivas Group

texts.es: El grupo “Mujeres Positivas” con 06 integrantes responsables y entusiastas. Sonia de 39 años es separada con 01 hijo dependiente. Ella se dedica al alquiler de  vehículos (taxi), lleva más de 1 año en esta actividad, gracias a su esfuerzo ha logrado comprarse un nuevo taxi. Solicitó el crédito para el mantenimiento de los taxis y de esta manera dar un mejor servicio a sus clientes. Seguir trabajando positivamente es su mayor deseo.  El grupo “Mujeres Positivas” agradece a las personas que hicieron posible éste crédito. Sonia se encuentra de pie, es la segunda del lado derecho y viste chaleco celeste.
texts.en:
The “Mujeres Positivas” group has 6 responsible and enthusiastic members. Sonia is 39 years old and is separated, with one dependent child. Se makes a living hiring out taxis. She has been in this business for over one year, and thanks to her hard work, she has managed to buy herself a new taxi. 

She is requesting a loan to service the taxis and in this way, offer her customers a better service. Her biggest dream is to continue working in a positive manner. The “Mujeres Positivas” group is grateful to those who made this loan possible. 

In the photo, Sonia is the second from the right, standing up wearing a blue jacket.

loans.use: to keep her taxis serviced, carry out technical checks and obtain permits to use them.

loans.name: Sugra

texts.en:
Sugra is a 42-year-old married woman and mother of five children. Her husband (also shown in the photo), some time ago, started a van driving business. He owns one Toyota van and needs some financial help. He will use the amount to buy new tires and pay for repair and maintenance costs of the van. 

Therefore, Sugra has requested a loan amount of 45,000 PKR (Pakistani rupees). She is in her sixth loan cycle and has shown good repayment behavior. She is thankful for previous loans from Kashf. She is hopeful that her husband’s business will prosper and their living standards will improve.

loans.use: to buy new tires and pay for repair and maintenance costs of the van.

loans.name: Rubyrina

texts.en:
Rubyrina is aged 49 and married. They're blessed with five children. She has managed a retail and food stall in front of their house for almost seven years. In this business, she's earning a net income of 500 PHP (Philippines pesos) daily. Her net income is usually spent on their daily expenses. 

Due to insufficient funds, she would like to avail a loan amounting to PHP 11,000 to purchase additional  food seasonings, vegetables, pork, and chicken to cook and to sell. She's hoping that her business will continue to grow and become more profitable.

loans.use: To purchase additional food seasonings, vegetables, pork, and chicken to cook and to sell.

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
Beatriz is 30 years old, married and had two children. She is raising hogs and selling them to butchers upon achieving the desired weight. Her income goes for her family's daily expenses such as meals. 

She is now asking for additional capital of 4,000 Philippines pesos to buy rice bran and medicine for the hogs. This loan will help improve the nutrition of the hogs, so she will be able to sell them at a higher cost someday. Beatriz hopes to become a successful hog grower someday.

loans.use: to buy rice bran and medicine for the hogs

loans.name: Ursulina

texts.en:
Ursulina is 66 years old and lives in Corrales, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is married with five children now at their adult age. 

For her means of living, Ursulina has been engaged in a dressmaking business for 50 years already. She earns approximately 4,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) each month doing this type of business activity. She has requested a loan to be used in purchasing additional cloth, threads and accessories for her dressmaking business. 

Ursulina has been a member of PMPC for almost seven years. In the future, Ursulina hopes to build a dress shop.

loans.use: To purchase additional cloth, threads and accessories

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en: Zainab is a Babban Gona farmer from Kwankwani. Zainab expressed that she is driven by one goal; to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Zainab to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, she finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Zainab can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Zainab, is ambitious and is aiming to reap yields above both the national and Babban Gona averages. By doing so, Zainab will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what she plans to do with her income from this season, she said: “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family.” With this loan, Zainab will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Hauwa

texts.en: Hauwa is a Babban Gona farmer from Rafin-Tabo. Hauwa is driven by one goal: to “make more money for myself and my family.” It is this ambition that led Hauwa to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, she finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Hauwa can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Hauwa, is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 40 bags per hectare this season because with this loan, she will finally be able to access the required yield enhancing inputs such as improved seeds. Hauwa is hoping that as a result of this expected yield, she will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what changes she would like to make, she said “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland.  Ultimately, I want to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, Hauwa will be able to access all the inputs and services to make these dreams reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Jibrin

texts.en: Jibrin remembers feeling down during a particularly bad harvest. This is before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, as a Babban Gona member, Jibrin can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. With access to high quality inputs, Jibrin is aiming to reap up to 35 bags per hectare this season.  Jibrin expressed that “in 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, Jibrin is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Salisu M

texts.en: Salisu remembers not being able to feed his family during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now Salisu like all Babban Gona members can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Salisu is ambitious and is aiming to reap 50 bags per hectare this season. “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community and provide for my three children Imrana, Hisbilla,and Kadijah” expressed Salisu. With this loan, Salisu is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
Linda is a 33-year-old married mother of two. She is a Syrian refugee who has been working hard with her husband to improve their newly established business since August 2013, in order to support their children in their living, and covering most of their living needs, through a good acquired income.

She started this business with a very small amount of capital that was invested in buying the requested tools and raw materials to start, but she still needs extra cash to develop her business and increase her production. 

Today, she is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to buy necessary raw materials to increase her business production and develop her family's living.

She hopes that she can provide her children with a better education, and develop her business more in the future to make sure that she can provide her family with a better living.

She hopes that one day Syria will find peace, and everything goes back to normal as it should be.

loans.use: To buy necessary raw materials to increase her business production and develop her family's living

loans.name: Yohana

texts.en: Yohana is a Babban Gona farmer from Maidawa. Yohana expressed that he is driven by one goal: to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Yohana to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Yohana can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Yohana is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Yohana will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family”. With this loan, Yohana will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Farhat

texts.en:
Thirty-five-year-old Farhat is married. With her husband’s inadequate salary it was difficult for Farhat to meet the food, health and clothing expenditures of the family. As a result, six years ago, she started a cloth trading business. She purchases good quality cloth from the wholesale market and sells it in her vicinity. 

She is in her sixth loan cycle and needs a loan of 40,000 PKR (Pakistani rupees) to purchase stock of cloth in various colors and designs for resale. She is hopeful that this loan will help her to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of cloth in various colors and designs.

loans.name: Sinignessigui 2 Group

texts.fr:
Les 9 membres du groupe  SINIGNESSIGUI 2 sont des hommes mariés  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 47 ans et ont en moyenne 8 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des  familles traditionnelles à NIARADOUGOU un village dans la commune de DANDERESSO dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Ils  collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils sont à leur cinquième prêt de production de maïs avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est de maïs  avec monsieur SALIFOU MAMADOU  débout à la deuxième  position de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo dans ce groupe d’homme SINIGNESSIGUI 2 . 
Avec son prêt, il compte acheter 14 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 20 bidons d’herbicide de qualité différente, payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir  3,5 hectares. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  520 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part de contribuer  les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The nine members of the Sinignessigui 2 Group are all married men who are, on average, 47 years old and have eight children.  Most of them live in traditional families in the village of Niaradougou, Danderesso commune, Sikasso region (third administrative region of Mali).  

The men work with the field partner, Soro Yiriwaso, during the winter season, in order to improve their agricultural businesses.  This will be their fifth maize production loan.  All the previous loans were fully and correctly repaid.

Salifou Mamadou (standing second from the right in the photo) grows maize.  He will use his loan to buy fourteen 50 kg sacks of fertilizer, twenty drums of various qualities of herbicide, and pay the labour costs to work 3.5 hectares of land.  After the harvest, he will sell the maize in the village, in Sikasso, to both men and women, on a cash or credit basis.

Salifou Mamadou expects to earn an average profit of 520,000 francs CFA over the loan period.  This will enable him to repay his loan and interest, and help to provide for the daily expenses of his family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pay for labour costs.

loans.name: Sinignessigui 3 Group

texts.fr:
Les 8 membres du groupe  SINIGNESSIGUI 3 sont des hommes mariés  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans et ont en moyenne 5 enfants et vivant la plupart  dans des  familles traditionnelles à NIARADOUGOU un village dans la commune de DANDERESSO dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Ils  collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Ils sont à leur cinquième prêt de production de maïs avec l’institution de microfinance soro yiriwaso, les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est de maïs  avec monsieur ISSA assise au milieu sur la photo dans ce groupe d’homme SINIGNESSIGUI 3. 
Avec son prêt, il compte acheter 14 sacs de 50 kg d’engrais, 20 bidons d’herbicide de qualité différente, payer les frais de labour  pour entretenir  3,5 hectares. 
Après la récolte la production est vendue au niveau du village, à SIKASSO à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de  520 000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer d’une part son prêt et son intérêt et d’autre part de contribuer  les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The eight members of the Sinignessigui 3 Group are all married men who are, on average, 36 years old and have five children.  Most of them live in traditional families in the village of Niaradougou, Danderesso commune, Sikasso region (third administrative region of Mali).  

The men work with the field partner, Soro Yiriwaso, during the winter season, in order to improve their agricultural businesses.  This will be their fifth maize production loan.  All the previous loans were fully and correctly repaid.

Issa (sitting in the middle in the photo) grows maize.  He will use his loan to buy fourteen 50 kg sacks of fertilizer, twenty drums of various qualities of herbicide, and pay the labour costs to work 3.5 hectares of land.  After the harvest, he will sell the maize in the village, in Sikasso, to both men and women, on a cash or credit basis.

Issa expects to earn an average profit of 520,000 francs CFA over the loan period.  This will enable him to repay his loan and interest, and help to provide for the daily expenses of his family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pay for labour costs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay off a personal debt that he has.

loans.name: Imrana

texts.en: Imrana is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Imrana is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Imrana will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Imrana can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year  as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Imrana is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his long term goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Erik

texts.en:
Erik lives in Serang, a semi-urban area about 2.5 hours from Jakarta. Erik is married and living with three people in the family home. He runs a small stall located in front of his house and sells mobile phone airtime credits. 

He began working with Ruma two months ago because he wanted to increase his income. He feels really excited to expand his business in selling mobile phone airtime credits and servicing bill payments. As the business runs, Erik hopes to get a Kiva loan as working capital in order to do more transactions on weekends.

loans.use: to process more mobile airtime credits transactions on weekends.

loans.name: Lolika Marida

texts.en:
Lolika is a candidate student at the Academy of Maritime Nusantara (AMN) of procedures studied in commerce and harbor administration. Lolika wants to work in a shipping office because she lives on the coast of Sumatra, precisely in the area of the border with the Province of Aceh, which was named Sibolga. It is populated by villagers working as fishermen and farmers. Likewise, the parents of Lolika, her father and mother, work as farmers to meet their daily needs. Lolika is the last child of seven siblings, and with a very minimal income, the parents struggle to send their children to higher education. 

Lolika just graduated from high school and wants to continue her studies in AMN. With the student loan program on AMN Kiva, she is very happy. Lolika said, "With this loan from Kiva, I am happy to still have a chance to experience college in AMN, and this became my motivation to get the best value." With work later, Lolika can help the family economy and can help her siblings to be able to attend school. 

Lolika also said, "I hope this student loan program will be growing and can provide the opportunity for people who want to grow and are determined to go to college." She is very grateful to Kiva lenders all around the world.

loans.use: to pay her education fees for three years.

loans.name: Issa

texts.fr:
Monsieur ISSA est né en Février 1960 à SIKASSO, marié, père de 2 enfants et il réside chez lui-même avec son épouse dans une famille traditionnelle à LAFIABOUGOU un quartier de NIENA une commune dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ième région administrative de la république du MALI. 
Monsieur ISSA mène des activités d’achat et de vente des herbicides il ya plus de 6 ans, il s'approvisionne à SIKASSO.
Il est à son premier prêt  individuel commerçant avec l’Institution de Microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante. 
Ce prêt lui permettra de faire l’achat de 10 cartons de 12 bidons herbicides de qualité différente à SIKASSO pour la revendre au détail à NIENA à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit.
 Il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 77 000 francs CFA par mois. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer le prêt et son intérêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Issa was born in February 1960 in Sikasso.  He is married, has two children and lives in a traditional family with his wife.  They live in Niena Commune, in the Sikasso district (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Issa has been buying and selling herbicides for more than six years.  He buys his stock in Sikasso.  This will be his first individual commercial loan with the field partner, Soro Yiriwaso.  He hopes to be better able to satisfy the demands of his customers by buying 10 boxes of 12 bottles of various quality of herbicide.  Issa retails his product in Niena to both men and women, for cash or on credit.

Issa expects to earn a monthly average profit of 77,000 francs CFA.  This will enable him to repay his loan and interest, and invest in his business.

loans.use: to buy herbicides for resale.

loans.name: Hauwa

texts.en: Hauwa remembers not being able to feed her family  during a particularly bad harvest. This is before she became a Babban Gona Member. Now, as a Babban Gona member, Hauwa like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the National average of 14. However, Hauwa,  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  Hauwa expressed that “In 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, Hauwa is well on her way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Issiaka

texts.fr:
Monsieur ISSIAKA est né vers 1966 à NIENA, marié, père de 3 enfants il réside chez lui-même avec son épouse dans une famille traditionnelle à SOKOURANI un quartier de NIENA une commune dans le cercle de SIKASSO 3ième région administrative de la république du MALI. 
Monsieur ISSIAKA mène des activités d’achat et de vente des herbicides il ya 5 ans, il s’approvisionne à SIKASSO.
Il est à son premier prêt  individuel commerçant avec l’Institution de Microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante. 
Ce prêt lui permettra de faire l’achat de 10 cartons de 12 bidons herbicides de qualité différente à SIKASSO pour la revendre au détail à NIENA à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit.
 Il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 77 000 francs CFA par mois. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer le prêt et son intérêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Issiaka was born around 1966 in Niena.  He is married, has three children and lives in a traditional family with his wife, in Sokourani neighbourhood, Niena Commune, Sikasso district (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Issiaka has been buying and selling herbicides for five years now.  He buys his stocks in Sikasso.  This will be his first individual commercial loan with the field partner, Soro Yiriwaso.  He hopes to be able to better satisfy the growing demands of his customers by buying 10 boxes of 12 bottles of various quality herbicide.  He will retail his product in Niena to both men and women, for cash or on credit.

Issiaka expects to earn a monthly average profit of 77,000 francs CFA.  This will enable him to repay his loan and interest, and invest in his business.

loans.use: to buy herbicides for resale.

loans.name: Yara Isabel

texts.es:
Una sonrisa cálida y mucho entusiasmo es lo que reciben las clientes al entrar a la casa de Yara Isabel, lugar donde está establecido su  pequeño salón de belleza, negocio que hace tres años le ha proporcionado estabilidad económica. Con 23 años de edad y con un hijo, se siente motivada por la ayuda que le brindado Kiva a través de MiCrédito, puesto que sin el financiamiento su negocio no hubiese prosperado, al mismo tiempo agradece el apoyo de su madre, juntas han incrementado la producción  y obtenido buenos ingresos.
Yara solicita un nuevo crédito para la compra de materiales de belleza, tales como bisuterías, tintes para el cabello, cremas faciales, pinturas de uñas, algodón, entre otros. Es una mujer con muchos sueños y metas, uno de ellos es convertir su pequeño salón de belleza en una escuela, donde ella pueda transmitir su conocimiento y sus estudiantes puedan progresar. Por lo tanto día a día esta mujer se levanta con muchas ganas de cambiar el mundo,  su herramienta será el trabajo para ofrecerle a su hijo salud y educación de calidad.
texts.en:
A warm smile and a lot of enthusiasm is what customers get when they go to the home of  Yara Isabel, where she has set up a small beauty salon. For three years, this business has brought her financial stability. At 23 years old and with a son, she feels motivated by the help offered by Kiva through MiCrédito. Without the financing her business wouldn't have prospered. She is also grateful for her mother's support. Together they have increased production and obtained good income.  

Yara is asking for a new loan to buy beauty supplies such as jewelry, hair dyes, face creams, nail polish, cotton, and more. She is a woman with a lot of dreams and goals. One of them is to convert her little beauty salon into a school where she can transmit her knowledge and her students can progress. That is why this woman gets up day day eager to change the world. Her tool will be her work to offer her son health and a quality education.

loans.use: to buy beauty supplies such as jewelry, hair dyes, face creams, nail polish, cotton, and more.

loans.name: Naseem

texts.en:
Naseem is a 38-year-old married woman who is living with her husband and six children. For many years, she has been in the work of embroidery on shoes. She makes embroidered patterns for shoes and sells them to businesses. She has managed to consolidate a clientele that allows her to contribute to the expenses of her household. 

To help continue her operations, she has requested a loan of 40,000 PKR to buy spools of thread, leather and packs of needles. She is in her fourth loan cycle and has shown good repayment behavior. 

Naseem dreams for her children's bright future.

loans.use: to buy spools of thread, leather and packs of needles.

loans.name: Caridi

texts.en:
Meet Caridi. He is a father of two who lives with two people in the family home in Indramayu, West Java. His spouse is a full-time housewife, taking care of their 5-year-old son. He manages a small stall that sells office supplies, stationery, and mobile phone airtime credits. 

He began working with Ruma a month ago because he wanted to increase his income. Since then, he became more aware of how mobile technology can support his business. As the business runs, Caridi hopes to get a Kiva loan as working capital in order to do more transactions on weekends.

loans.use: to process more mobile phone airtime credit sales on weekends.

loans.name: Mwaniki

texts.en:
This is Charles. He is a final year student at the Presbyterian University of East Africa studying for a Bachelor's Degree in Supplies Management. He comes from a family of 5, his mother is a business lady who specializes in selling retail and wholesale chemical detergents while his father is a bank teller in Eldoret, Kenya. 

His vision is to finish his education and become self-employed by starting his own business, like his mother. He intends to engage in agribusiness and supply products from his farm by selling them in wholesale. A loan from Kiva will help Charles complete his education, become self-reliant and help his community by applying his knowledge in business.

loans.use: to pay for tuition fees and educational costs.

loans.name: Josphine Wangui

texts.en: This is Josephine from Kiambu Kenya.She is a mother, farmer and business lady. She has educated her children through revenue from the farming. She also buys and sells potatoes in wholesale. A loan from Kiva will assist her to ease transport of her farm produce so that it gets to the market on time.

loans.use: to pay for transportation of farm produce

loans.name: Haruna

texts.en: Haruna is a Babban Gona farmer from Nassarawa. Haruna expressed that he is driven by one goal; to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Haruna to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Haruna can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Haruna, is ambitious and is aiming to reap yields higher than both the national and Babban Gona averages. By doing so, Haruna will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland.” With this loan, Haruna will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Musa Barau

texts.en: Musa Barau remembers not being able to feed his family  during a particularly bad harvest. This is before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, as a Babban Gona member, Musa Barau like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the National average of 14. However, Musa Barau,  is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 40 bags per hectare this season due to the high-quality inputs that he will purchase with this loan.  When asked about the future, Musa Barau said: “In 5 years, I want to ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty.” With this loan, Musa Barau is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Paul Kiratu

texts.en:
This is Paul. He has been doing farming since he was young. He farms vegetables, horticultural products and keeps dairy cattle. To get to this level, he has mostly been leasing land. Paul's vision is have his own land instead of leasing to lower the cost of agricultural production. He wants to build a model farm. 

A loan from Kiva helps Paul finance costs of getting his own land and buy farm inputs.

loans.use: to pay for costs of buying parcel of land and inputs

loans.name: Ann Njeri

texts.en: Ann is a mother of one and a farmer. She runs a farm together with her husband and they are dedicated in its  operations. She currently has five dairy cows producing 30 litres of milk per day. She intends to buy another cow and expand the cowshed with help of a loan from Kiva.

loans.use: to pay for purchase of another cow and expand the cowshed

loans.name: Agnes Chepng'etich

texts.en: Agnes is a farmer and a mother of six. She has been doing dairy farming for over 30 years and currently has six dairy cows. She supplies milk from her farm to hotels. A loan from Kiva will assist her in purchasing a motorbike to ease in transportation of milk in support of her business.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for transportation of her milk produce

loans.name: Jane Nyambura

texts.en: This is Jane from Muranga Kenya. She is a wife, farmer and business woman. She grows bananas, cultivates tea and rears a dairy cow. She sells her produce from the farm to earn an upkeep for her family. She intends to use the kiva loan to buy one dairy cow and increase her income through sale of milk.

loans.use: to pay for one dairy cow

loans.name: Emprendedoras Group

texts.es:
El comité se llama Emprendedoras es un grupo antiguo que está bastante bien. El comité tiene 15 mujeres todas con un objetivo en común, ayudar a mejorar la situación de vida de sus familias. 
Una de las integrantes de comités es la señora Elvira quien se dedica a la venta de comidas, es una señora muy trabajadora que con su esfuerzo día a día va acrecentando su negocio y se hace conocida en el barrio.
El préstamo ella lo pide para poder invertirlo en la compra de insumos varios para poder hacer sus comidas, como verduras, condimentos, carne, aderezos y demás, y de esa forma seguir con sus ventas, con lo cual ayuda a sus familias.
texts.en:
This committee is called Emprendedoras. It is an old group that is doing very well. The committee has 15 women with a common goal: helping improve their families' life situations.  
 
One of the members of the committee is Elvira. She sells food. She is a very hardworking woman who strives day to day to grow her business and become known in the neighborhood. The loan she is asking for is to buy various materials to make her food, such as vegetables, seasonings, dressings and more. This way she can continue with her sales and help her family.

loans.use: to buy vegetables, seasonings, meat, dressings and more.

loans.name: Roxanne

texts.en: Roxanne is 20 years old and a hog grower living at Solana with her family. She raises and sells hogs upon achieving the desired weight.She would like to ensure good nutrition to grow her hogs, which is why she is asking for additional capital of P 4,000 to buy medicine and vaccine for the hogs. She hopes to acquire more profits and save it for the family. She also promises to pay back her loan in full.

loans.use: to buy medicine and vaccine for hogs sustenance

loans.name: Soknao Group

texts.en:
Soknao is 62 years old, a farmer and a widowed woman with a child. Her child is a blacksmith. She has been a farmer since 1994. They live in Tbong Khmum Province, Cambodia. Both of them can earn approximately $12 per day. 

Now Soknao would like to request a loan as a group of four members, and she will use her portion to buy concrete sewers to build a latrine. This loan will help her live in better conditions and avoid illnesses. 

In the future, she is going to have another business and renovate her house.

loans.use: to buy concrete sewers to build a latrine.

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia is 32 years old and lives in Sta. Cruz, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is widowed with 1 child now at school age. 
Delia has been engaged in the duck raising business for almost 3 years. She earns approximately PHP 2,500.00 each month doing this type of business activity. She has requested a loan to be used in purchasing additional ducklings, booster and grower feed for her duck raising business. 
Delia has been a member of PMPC for 2 years. In the future, Delia hopes to expand her duck raising business.

loans.use: To be used in purchasing additional ducklings, booster and grower feed

loans.name: Ma. Teresita

texts.en:
Ma. Teresita has faithfully paid back her previous loan, which she used for her business. She has been operating her own “sari-sari” (variety) store for years, and she earns well from this. Having a bigger family requires more effort to provide for their needs, especially for her two children. She had to work hard, with the determination of having better income to provide for her family.

To improve sales, Ma. Teresita would like to apply for a new loan to purchase additional grocery goods to sell. With PHP 20,000, she could already purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business. She sincerely lets you know her heartfelt thanks and appreciation for this assistance in advance.

In the future, Ma. Teresita dreams for her children to have a good life. She hopes to grow her business more and become successful. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her life and business and also to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the word of God that she studies.

*All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather to study the word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for groceries, toiletries and beverages needed for her business.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is 64 years old and married with six children.

Teresita works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 12000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

Teresita has borrowed and repaid 18 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for nine years and also earns an income from pig fattening.

Teresita aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 35 years old and married with three children.

She earns a living by having a pig fattening business in the Philippines. Grace is borrowing PHP 12000 through NWTF to buy additional piglets, feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Grace has been in pig fattening for 6 years and also earns additional income from selling herbal products and jewelry.

She is working tirelessly towards the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional piglets, feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is a married woman with four children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Janet is 32 years old and three of her children are currently in school.

Janet has a business selling jewelry in the Philippines. Janet has requested a PHP 18,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase more stock of jewelry to sell to her customers.

Janet has been in this business for six years. In the future, Janet would like to save enough money to afford sending her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of jewelry to sell to her customers

loans.name: Thelma

texts.en:
Thelma is 43 years old and married with four children. With all four children in school, Thelma works very hard to provide for them.

Thelma runs a general store in the Philippines, and she has requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy more groceries to sell.

Thelma has been in this business for ten years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, canned goods, soft drinks and other groceries. 

In the future, Thelma would like to save money to expand her business and continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Dama

texts.en:
Dama is married with five children, three of whom are still in school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. 

Dama operates a coconut selling business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.   

With the Kshs 25,000 loan she wants to purchase seven sacks of coconuts to resell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase seven sacks of coconuts to resell

loans.name: Alh. Abdulrazak

texts.en: Alh. Abdulrazak is a 53-year-old farmer from Kwankwani.  As a Babban Gona member, Alh. Abdulrazak is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Alh. Abdulrazak can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Alh. Abdulrazak is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 40 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Alh. Abdulrazak is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children; Muhammed,  and  Abubakar. Alh. Abdulrazak’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Hermosilla

texts.en:
Hermosilla is 52 years old and married with three children. 

She is in the agricultural business, pig fattening in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Hermosilla has been in pig fattening for five years now, and has borrowed three times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

Hermosilla would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Nerayda

texts.es:
La socia Nerayda  se dedica al negocio de agencia de viajes,la socia trabaja con personas extranjeras y nacionales, la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 6:00 p.m,la socia ya tiene varios años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño del socio es ampliar el negocio de agencia de viajes. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar boletos turísticos.


La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en: Nerayda  works in a travel agency. She works with foreigners and people from her country. She works from 8 am until 6 pm. She has been in this business for a number of years and things are going very well for her. Her dream is to expand her travel agency business. She is requesting the loan to buy tourist's tickets. Nerayda is happy with the loan and promises to pay the installments of her loan on time.

loans.use: to buy tourist tickets.

loans.name: Ingrid

texts.en:
Hog-raising is the business of Ingrid and where she gets income for her family. She is 35 years old and married. She sells her hogs to butchers upon achieving the desired weight. She usually gains about PHP 2,000 for each hog disposal. 

She wanted to give enough nourishment to hogs, so that is why she is asking for a loan of PHP 4,000 to buy rice bran and feed for the hogs’ sustenance. With good sales, she will be able to buy more hogs to feed and keep improving her profits as well.

loans.use: to buy rice bran and feed for her hogs' sustenance.

loans.name: Princesita

texts.en:
Princesita is 44 years old, married and has two children. She manages a store selling grocery items and food for daily meals and snacks. She has been in her business for over four years and provides good, friendly service to her customers. 

Princesita would like to increase her merchandise, which is why she is asking for a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy sardines, eggs, meat and vegetables to cook and sell. This will help increase sales capacity, which in turn will help her earn good profits. Someday, she hopes to develop her store into a bigger one.

loans.use: to buy sardines, eggs, meat and vegetables to cook and sell

loans.name: Marjo

texts.en:
Marjo is a 30-year-old single man. He lives with his parents and his sisters. He has been running the business of poultry for years. Six years ago he focused on becoming a distributor of chicken. Commonly, he takes from Kupang around 500 chickens and sells them to the market and his customers around Soe. 

The income from this business enabled him to buy a car to deliver the chicken. 

Currently, he needs cash to buy more chicken and fuel for the business operation. Therefore, he requested a loan of IDR 15,000,000 from TLM. The loan will be spent on more chicken and fuel for his car.

loans.use: to buy more chicken and fuel for his car.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah operates a poultry selling business, and that is where she gets her income. She mentioned a disease outbreak causing losses as a challenge in the business. Sarah dreams of becoming a wholesaler of poultry in the future. 

With the KES 40,000, she wants to purchase chicks and poultry feed. She joined Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase chicks and poultry feed.

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny is 36 years old, married, and has two children, one of whom is currently in school.

Jenny is in the agricultural business, pig fattening in the Philippines. Jenny has been in pig fattening for three years now, and she has borrowed seven times in the past from NWTF to sustain it. 

Jenny requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

Jenny would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Teresa Marleni

texts.es:
Teresa de 29 años de edad, estudio hasta séptimo grado. Por la situación económica de su familia ya no pudo seguir estudiando. Es casada y su esposo se dedica a trabajar como agente de seguridad en la alcaldía municipal. Tienen dos hijas la 1ra tiene 9 años y estudia 3er grado, la segunda tiene tres años aun no estudia, con ella solo viven sus hijas y su esposo.


Teresa  por el momento no tiene una actividad que le genere ingresos solo se dedica al cuido de sus hijas, sus ingresos dependen de la ayuda de su esposo, no tiene ninguna actividad productiva porque hace aproximadamente 3 meses la ataco una enfermedad que le impidió seguir con el pequeño negocio que tenía, ella vendía verduras, su esposo era quien la apoyaba en traer la verdura desde la ciudad.

El préstamo que esta solicitando a CREDICAMPO,  es para cancelar una deuda que tiene, ya que cuando se enfermó tuvo que recurrir a buscar quien le prestara para sus gastos en la medicina, también va comprar verdura para empezar nuevamente con su negocio ya que es algo que le es rentable.  Con el crédito podrá tener sus negocio comprar lo que necesita y así tener ingresos económicos para cubrir los gastos familiares junto a su esposo.



   El sueño de Teresa, es que sus hijas se preparen académicamente, antes dice que veían lejos tener una casa más adecuada para su familia como la tienen hoy, pero gracias al esfuerzo de su esposo lo han logrado,  y así como pudieron salir adelante dice que pretenden dar lo mejor para sus hijas para que puedan salir adelante y ayudar a otros que lo necesitan, y contribuir a tener  un mejor país.
texts.en:
Teresa is 29 years old and studied up to Grade 7. Due to her family's economic situation she couldn't continue her studies. She is married and her husband works as a security guard for the Municipal government. She has two children, the first is 9 years old and is in Grade 3. The second is only 3 years old and doesn't study yet. Just her and her husband and children live together.
  
At the moment Teresa does not have an activity that generates income, she just takes care of her daughters. Her revenue depends on the help of her husband. She has no activity because about 3 months ago she got sick that stopped her from running her small business. She sold vegetables. Her husband helped her to transport the vegetables from the city. 

The loan that she is requesting from CrediCampo is to cancel a debt that she has. When she was sick she had to find someone to lend her the money for the expense of the medicine. She is also going to buy vegetables to re-open her business as it is something that is profitable. With the loan she will be able to have her business by buying what is necessary and thus she will have revenues to pay for the family expenses along with her husband. 

Teresa's dream is to prepare her children academically. Before she used to say that it seemed very far away to having an adequate home like the one they have today, but thanks to the efforts of her husband they have succeeded. So they can continue to progress hoping to provide the best for their daughters so they can get ahead and help others that need it and contribute to having a better country.

loans.use: to pay off a debt and to buy vegetables to restart her business.

loans.name: Yakubu Aikau

texts.en: Yakubu Aikau remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Yakubu Aikau, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Yakubu Aikau  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family” expressed Yakubu Aikau   With this loan, Yakubu Aikau is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Barani

texts.en:
Barani is a married woman and has children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past six years, she has operated a food kiosk business, selling food like maize flour and cooking fat to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned high costs and seasonality as her major challenges. Barani dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, sugar, and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, sugar, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en: Julius is married with five children, aged 24, 22, 20, 8 and 5 years. He is 48 years old.  He has applied for a loan of 3,000,000 (three million shillings) to buy manure, mulches and labor for his agriculture business. He is a farmer in his local area of Ruhinda, Mitooma.  He also trades in coffee and produce to supplement on his income.  He started farming in the year 2000 from his local area and his clients are coffee and matooke (banana) traders.  He hopes to educate all his children for a better future. He is a very hard working man, but faced with the challenge of banana and coffee bacteria wilt, a disease that has affected his cash flow. He hopes to continue working hard and boost his businesses after getting the loan. He is appreciative of the Kiva lenders contribution towards his business.

loans.use: To buy organic manure

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a laptop and a generator and to renovate his workplace.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cement, sand, flooring bricks and to pay for labor to lay the bricks and buy a window.

loans.name: Cesar

texts.es: El señor Cesar, vive en la población de Entre Ríos del Trópico de Cochabamba, es soltero y no tiene hijos, se dedica al sector de la carpintería, específicamente a la realización de vigas y listones, su producción la comercializa en el mismo lugar de la actividad económica, también trabaja a pedido, es una persona responsable y trabajadora, siempre con el anhelo de salir adelante desde muy joven se vino al trópico desde el altiplano de potosí a buscar mejores condiciones de vida, asi emprendió su actividad hace dos años atrás, ahora solicita un crédito para la compra de una máquina para su trabajo de carpintería, con esta herramienta realizara de manera más eficiente su trabajo y empezara la realización de otros muebles.
texts.en: César lives in the town of Entre Ríos in the Trópico de Cochabamba. He is single and has no children. He makes his living as a carpenter, making beams and slats. He sells his products in the same place where he makes them, and he also takes special orders. He is a responsible and hardworking person who has always had the desire to succeed. At a young age he came to the tropics from the highlands of Potosí to seek better living conditions, and he started his profession two years ago. He is requesting a loan to purchase a machine for woodwork; with this tool he will be able to carry out his work more efficiently and begin to make other furniture.

loans.use: to purchase a machine for woodwork.

loans.name: Las Puntuales Group

texts.es: . Janet de 40 años de edad soltera  y no tiene hijo. Janet   es una mujer muy emprendedora que gracias  a sus esfuerzos a sabido superarse,  Janet   tiene una pequeña academia de baile y steps, Janet es profesora de aeróbicos y cosmiatria,  Con el préstamo otorgado lo invertirá en comprar más accesorios para su negocio de baile, Janet se le distingue por su casaca de color blanco, la vez  se encuentra muy agradecida por la ayuda brindada, se despide con un fuerte abraso Kiva, sabiendo que cumplirá todas sus metas.
texts.en: Janet is 40 years old, single and doesn't have children. She is an enterprising woman who has got ahead in life thanks to her own effort. Janet owns a small dancing and step academy. She is a teacher of aerobics and advanced cosmetology. she will invest the money from the loan in the purchase of more accessories for her dancing business. Janet is the woman wearing the white jacket in the picture. She is very grateful for the help provided and sends a big hug to Kiva, knowing that she will reach her goals.

loans.use: to purchase accessories for her dancing business

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer, age 41, is married and blessed with three children. She has owned and managed a water refilling station in their village for almost 2 1/2 years and earns a net income of PHP 500 daily.  She also sells snacks in their village for an additional source of income.

Due to a lack of capital to run her business, she would like to avail a loan amounting to PHP 10,000 to purchase five-gallon containers of mineral water to sell. She's hoping that her requested loan will be granted so that she can improve her business to earn more income.

loans.use: To purchase five-gallon containers of mineral water to sell.

loans.name: Julie

texts.en:
Julie is 52 years old and married, with three children.  

Julie is in the agricultural business, pig-fattening in the Philippines. She has requested a PHP 12,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Julie has been in pig-fattening for five years now and has borrowed three times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

Julie would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is single and has a business raising pigs in the Philippines.

Janet requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

She has been in this business for two years now.

In the future, Janet would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet operates a fruits and vegetables selling stall. She sells at the market to town dwellers and neighbors. She faces a challenge of competition and seasonality in her business. 

Here again she comes to you requesting a loan of KES 30,000. She wants to purchase sacks of fruits and potatoes, oranges, bananas and green vegetables for resale. 

She dreams of expanding and establishing a retail shop in the future.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fruits and potatoes, oranges, bananas and green vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Ezekiel Danjuma

texts.en: Ezekiel Danjuma remembers not being able to feed his family  during a particularly bad harvest. This is before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, as a Babban Gona member, Ezekiel Danjuma like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the National average of 14. However, Ezekiel Danjuma,  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  Ezekiel Danjuma expressed that “In 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family.” With this loan, Ezekiel Danjuma is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Sabiu

texts.en: Sabiu is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Sabiu is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Sabiu will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, he would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where the products are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Sabiu can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2000/ha: more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make this year as a Babban Gona member, he said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Sabiu is not thinking about this year alone; he expressed that his long term goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Elvira

texts.es: Elvira de 60 años de edad vive con su 2 hijas de 22 y 17 años de edad. Ella es una mujer tenaz que se gana la vida prestando sus servicios domésticos. Elvira desea construir un cuarto en su propiedad por lo que solicita un crédito a FUSAI para comprar los siguientes materiales: cemento, arena, grava, hierro y ladrillo, además deberá pagar mano de obra para la construcción del cuarto en su propiedad.
texts.en: Elvira, 60, lives with two daughters aged 22 and 17. She is a tenacious woman who makes her living working as a domestic servant. Elvira wants to build a room in her house, so she has asked the field partner, FUSAI, for a loan to purchase the following materials: cement, sand, gravel, iron and bricks. She will also need to pay the labor costs for building the room.

loans.use: to purchase cement, sand, gravel, iron and bricks. she will also pay for labor costs to build a room in her property.

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es: Carlos de 59 años de edad habita en casa propia con su esposa y su hija de 12 años de edad. Él es un hombre trabajador que desde hace 30 años se gana la vida como jornalero por lo que es muy conocido en su cantón. Carlos desea encementar el piso del patio de su vivienda, además quiere reparar el techo ya que este se encuentra bastante deteriorado por lo que solicita a FUSAI un crédito para comprar cemento, arena, grava y pagar mano de obra para la mejora del piso del patio y comprará teja para reparar el techo de su vivienda.
texts.en: Carlos is 59 years old and lives in his own house with his wife and his 12 year old daughter. He is a hard-working man who for the past 30 years has earned his living as day labor for which he is well-known in his canton. Carlos wants to cement in the patio of his house and he also wants to repair the roof of his house which is quite deteriorated. So he is requesting a loan from FUSAI to buy cement, sand and gravel and to pay for labor to improve the floor of the patio and repair the roof of his house.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand, gravel, and to pay for labor to cement over the floor of his patio and to buy tile to repair the roof of his house.

loans.name: Nozigul

texts.en:
Nozigul was born in 1960. She is a responsible mother of two children. She is going to start own business and in this way, find a source of income. 

Nozigul decided to start a business selling clothes and perfume. She studied at a course called "To Get Ahead" presented by a women's organization and got a certificate. She will sell clothes and perfume in a local market. She hopes her business will go well. She is asking for a loan of 4,700 somoni (TJS) to buy clothes and perfume. She awaits your mercy.

loans.use: To buy clothes and perfume for organizing a new business

loans.name: Mathew

texts.en: Mathew is a 46-year-old farmer from Nassarawa Murga.  As a Babban Gona member, Mathew, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Mathew can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Mathew is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to acces quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 40 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Mathew is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children; Joshua,  and  Yuwana,. Mathew’s dreams do not end here: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Abdu

texts.en: Abdu is a dedicated farmer from Kaduna State.  As a Babban Gona member, Abdu, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Abdu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Abdu is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will result in a yield of a total of  80 bags this season.  Abdu is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children; Markus, Joel, and Sunday. Abdu's dreams do not end there: “Ultimately, I want to make more money for myself and my family” he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Mujeres Triunfadoras De Micaela Bastidas Group

texts.es: REYNA  de 50  años de edad conviviente y con 1 hijo,Reyna  tiene un  pequeño negocio de venta de ropa  ya hace unos 24  años. Reyna  ha llegado a fidelizar  a sus clientes  el cual le ha generado ganancias para poder cubrir los gastos de su hogar,  En el futuro le gustaría tener un local propio donde poder vender sus productos y obtener mayores ganancias económicas. Con el préstamo otorgado lo invertirá en comprar más  ropa tanto para damas como para caballeros  y  así seguir satisfaciendo las necesidades de sus clientes   y así poder salir adelante. A la vez  Reyna y todos los integrantes se encuentran  agradecidos   con Kiva  por el préstamo otorgado   y por la confianza que se  les ha sido brindada. Reyna  es la del medio (casaca ploma) Se despide  Dejando la promesa  que cumplirá todas sus metas propuestas.
texts.en:
Reyna, 50, lives with her partner and she has a son. She has owned a small clothing business for about 24 years. Reyna has built the loyalty of her customers, which has provided the income to cover the household expenses. In the future she would like to own a store from which to sell her products in order to increase her profit. Reyna will invest the money from the loan in the purchase of more clothes for men and women so that she can meet her customers' demands and keep getting ahead in life.
Reyna and all the other members of the Communal Bank are grateful to Kiva for the support provided and for the confidence bestowed on them. Reyna is the woman in the middle of the picture (with the grey jacket). She promises to meet all her proposed objectives.

loans.use: to purchase clothes.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more goods for her grocery store.

loans.name: Gulbahor

texts.ru: Гулбахор добрая женщина. Ей 55 лет. Она замужем и имеет 4 детей. Гулбахор вместе со своей семьей живет на Севере Таджикистана. Она занимается уже более 19 лет выращиванием пшеницы. Также она откармливает скота. Гулбахор является собственником бизнеса и успешно справляется. Ее муж помогает ей введению бизнеса. Гулбахор в течение года выращивает два раза. Она хочет сделать второй посев и с такой целью она запрашивает займ на сумму 7000 сомони для покупки семена и минерального удобрения. Она ждет вашу доброту.
texts.en: Gulbahor is a kind woman. She is 55 years old. She is married and has 4 children. Gulbahor and her family live in the north of Tajikistan. She has been involved in growing wheat for over 19 years. Gulbahor is the owner of this business and handles it successfully. Her husband helps her with running the business. Gulbahor plants crops twice per year. She wants to do a second sowing and is requesting a loan in the amount of 7000 somoni to achieve this goal and buy seeds and mineral fertilizers. She awaits your kindness.

loans.use: to buy seeds and mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Yahaya

texts.en: Yahaya remembers not being able to build a new house  during a particularly bad harvest. This is before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now, as a Babban Gona member, Yahaya like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the National average of 14. However, Yahaya,  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season.  Yahaya expressed that “In 5 years, I want to move to the city with my family.” With this loan, Yahaya is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Jonnalyn

texts.en:
Jonnalyn is single and has a firewood vending business in the Philippines. Jonnalyn has been in this business for five years now.

Jonnalyn requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stocks of firewood to sell to her customers.

In the future, Jonnalyn would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of firewood to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Felisa

texts.en:
Felisa works hard to support her family. Felisa is married and has a retail business selling dried coconut meat in the Philippines.

Felisa requested a PHP 23,000 loan through NWTF to buy more sacks of dried coconut meat to sell.

Felisa has been in this business for 20 years now.

In the future, Felisa would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of dried coconut meat to sell

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is a 35-year-old married father. He is a Palestinian refugee who has worked as a fisherman for 20 years. Mohamad adores the sea; he was born a fisherman and can't imagine himself working in anything else.

Mohamad is a hardworking man. He has been an Al Majmoua borrower for eight consecutive loan cycles. All his previous loans were invested in his business and had a very good impact.

His previous loans and business improvement helped him a lot in increasing his income and improving his family's social and financial situations. 

Through this current acquired loan, Mohamad will make necessary maintenance to his boat to keep it in good shape to improve his living.

He is a man with a very good reputation, liked by most of his relatives and friends.
 
He hopes to buy a bigger boat in the future and to increase the number of boats he owns.

loans.use: To make necessary maintenance to his boat to keep it in good shape to improve his living.

loans.name: Mairamhan

texts.ru: Майрамхан 55 лет, замужем, мать 3 детей. У Майрамхан - высшее образование,по специальности товаровед в качестве основного дохода для своей семьи, она занимается животноводством, стартовав 24 года назад, с покупки скота на 15,000 сом (KGS). Благодаря упорному труду Майрамхан, в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеется: 2 дойные коровы, 5 овец, 2 лошади, 2 бычка. Дополнительным доходом являются заработки детей, которые находятся за рубежом. Ежемесячный доход Майрамхан составляет 18,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Майрамхан обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на покупку скота, часть средств будет направлена на постройку сарая. Доходы от кредита Майрамхан планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины.
texts.en: Mairamhan is 55 years old, married and a mother of 3 children. Mairamhan has a higher education and is a merchandiser. To provide the primary source of income for her family, she is involved in animal husbandry, having started this business 24 years ago with a 15,000 som (KGS) purchase of livestock.
