Thanks to Mairamhan's hard work, today her business contains 2 dairy cows, 5 sheep, 2 horses and 2 bulls. Her children's salaries from their work abroad provide an additional income. Mairamhan's monthly income amounts to 18,000 som (KGS). In order to further develop her business, Mairamhan requested a loan in the amount of 100,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum" Bank to buy livestock, and use part of the money to build a barn. Mairamhan plans to invest the earnings from the loan into further increasing the domestic livestock quantities.

loans.use: to buy livestock and build a barn

loans.name: Lutchia

texts.en:
Lutchia is 46 years old, married and has a school-age child. 

She and her spouse are involved in selling cans of cooking oil to retail stores at their village. They patiently manage this business in order to gain enough income for the family. 

Lutchia wants to buy more cooking oil to deliver but has insufficient funds. That is why she is now asking for a loan of PHP 13,000. This will help increase their sales to stores. She hopes to keep achieving good income and acquire regular customers too. She will save additional revenue for her child's education expenses.

loans.use: to buy more cooking oil to sell.

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
Liza is 38 years old, has five children, and lives in Enrile. She relies on income from buying and selling junk products for profit, such as empty cans, bottles, and old newspapers. She is proud of her business because it provides sustenance for the family. 

Liza is now asking for a loan of PHP 7,000 to buy more bottles, cans, and boxes to sell. She will invest her loan properly and will continue achieving good profits for her family's welfare.

loans.use: to buy more bottles, cans, and boxes to sell.

loans.name: Tijani

texts.en: Tijani is a farmer from Kwari.  As a Babban Gona member, Tijani is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Tijani can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the national average of 14. However, Tijani is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  When asked how he plans to spend the income he will make as a Babban Gona member, his said, “I plan to use the money  to educate my children; Aisha,Halliru, and Sumaiya. My overall goal is to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Ayuba

texts.en: Ayuba is a Babban Gona farmer from Nassarawa Murga. Ayuba expressed that he is driven by one goal; to “make more money for myself and my family.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Ayuba to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Ayuba can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Ayuba, is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 35 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Ayuba will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family”. With this loan, Ayuba will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Jaime Alberto

texts.es: Jaime de 23 años de edad vive con su compañera de vida y su hija de 8 meses. Él es un hombre tenaz que se dedica desde hace 5 años al oficio de enderezado y pintura de vehículos en un taller cercano a su cantón. Jaime desea colocar techo a su vivienda la cual actualmente como se observa en la fotografía solo cuenta con las paredes es por ello que solicita un crédito a FUSAI esperando obtener la aprobación de este lo antes posible para poder comprar polines, pernos, lámina galvanizada y pines para colocar el techo a su vivienda.
texts.en: Jaime, 23, lives with his live-in partner and their 8-month-old daughter. He is a tenacious man who has worked in a vehicle body work and paint workshop for 5 years. The workshop is close to his canton. Jaime wants to put roofing to his home, which at the moment, as can be seen in the picture, only has walls. That is why he is asking for a loan through the field partner, FUSAI, hoping to get approval as soon as possible so that he can buy beams, bolts, galvanized metal sheets and fasteners to put the roof on his house.

loans.use: to purchase beams, bolts, galvanized metal sheets and fasteners.

loans.name: Annah

texts.en:
Annah is a businesswoman in Kizinda, where her drug shop business is located. She is a mother of four children and she is 42 years old. 

She started the business in the year 1994 with an objective to financially support her family and also to pay school tuition for all her children. She also has a butchery, in addition to the drug shop business, and she says this helps her a lot since it gives her additional income which she uses to cater to the needs of the family. Her clients are people around Ishaka who go to her to buy drugs for their sick relatives. 

Annah's main challenge is competition since there are several drug shops in the same area where she operates from, but she believes that if she is given a loan of UGX 5,000,000, she will restock the drug shop and will out-compete her competitors. 

Her future hope includes establishing other drug shop outlets, so that she makes more sales and earns more profits. She is hopeful that the financial support will help her to further grow her business.

loans.use: to buy medicine for her drug shop.

loans.name: Yeti

texts.en:
Yeti is a 27-year-old single lady. She is living with her parents. She has been running a poultry business for four years. She initiated the business by using her own capital. She raised 50 chicks when she started the business. Now she has about 200 chicks that are being raised. It takes a month to raise the chicks before selling them to customers. 

Currently, she needs more money to sterilize the coop before she buys more chicks. This situation led her to request an individual loan from TLM of IDR 15,000,000. The loan will be spent on sterilizing the coop and buying more chicks.

loans.use: to buy more chicks and sterilize the coop

loans.name: Kabiru

texts.en: Kabiru is a 43-year- old farmer from Nassarawa Murga. As a Babban Gona member, Kabiru, is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Kabiru can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare,  double the National average of 14. However, Kabiru is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season. When asked, Kabiru said “I plan to use the money I make to educate my children; Micah,  Dianah, and  Jeneth, and in 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double yield and income

loans.name: Iliya

texts.en: Iliya remembers not being able to feed his family  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Iliya, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Iliya  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 40 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community” expressed Iliya   With this loan, Iliya is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Auwalu

texts.en: Auwalu is a Babban Gona farmer from Gimbawa. Auwalu expressed that he is driven by one goal: to “move to the city with my family.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Auwalu to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Auwalu can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Auwalu is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 40 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Auwalu will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to build a better home”. With this loan, Auwalu will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Harun

texts.en: Harun is a Babban Gona farmer from Gimbawa. Harun expressed that he is driven by one goal: to “make more money for myself and my family.” It is the desire to fulfil this ambition that led Harun to join Babban Gona. Now, as a Babban Gona member, he finally has the opportunity to access credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Harun can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Harun is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 40 bags per hectare this season. By doing so, Harun will finally have enough money to make significant life changes. When asked what he plans to do with his income from this season, he said: “I plan to use the money I make to provide more food and clothing for my family”. With this loan, Harun will be able to access all the inputs and services to make this dream a reality.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Alh. Isiyaku

texts.en: Alh. Isiyaku is a 50-year-old farmer from Gimbawa.  As a Babban Gona member, Alh. Isiyaku is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Alh. Isiyaku can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Alh. Isiyaku is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to acces quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 35 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Alh. Isiyaku is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children:  Anas,  Aminu,  and  Ali. Alh. Isiyaku’s dreams do not end here: “ultimately, I want to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs”, he said.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Dauda Maitala

texts.en: Dauda Maitala is a 40-year-old farmer from Gayya.  As a Babban Gona member, Dauda Maitala is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Dauda Maitala can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare; double the national average of 14. However, Dauda Maitala is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to access quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will  result in a yield of at least 40 bags of maize per hectare this season.  Dauda Maitala is hopeful about what the future holds; he  hopes that with the increased income as a result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children; Kyauta,  and  Roben. Dauda Maitala’s dreams do not end there: “ultimately, I want to make more money for myself and my family”, he expressed.

loans.use: To purchase high-quality inputs in order to double maize yield and income

loans.name: Ramos Petronila

texts.es:
A través de las calles turísticas más transitadas en Panajachel y Santiago Atitlán, Sololá, se encuentra una de las tiendas de ropa típica más atractiva debido a la simpática Petronila con su dote de vendedora impulsiva.

Soltera, de 20 años, viviendo con sus padres en este departamento ha elegido éstos lugares de mucho ambiente turístico desde hace un año.

Pero Ramos no se conforma con una venta mínima de su negocio, ella, emprendedora muchacha, tiene un sueño, sencillo pero ambicioso: ampliar su negocio con una vistosa variedad de trajes típicos de la región.

Es la razón que la mueve para solicitar un préstamo ya que sólo así sus sueños ambiciosos han de realizarse.
texts.en:
By going through the streets that are most traveled by tourists in Panajachel and Santiago Atitlán, Sololá you will find one of the most attractive typical clothing stores.  This is due to charming Petronila and her instinctive gift for sales.

She is 20 years old and single.  She is living with her parents in this department.  A year ago she chose places with a large tourist environment.

Ramos is not satisfied with minimum sales in her business.  She is an enterprising girl with a dream, which is simple but ambitious.  Her dream is to expand her business with an attractive variety of typical clothing from the region.

That is the reason that she is requesting a loan.  Only this way will her ambitious dreams be realized.

loans.use: to expand her business.

loans.name: Gulnara

texts.ru: Гулнара, 45 лет, замужем, мать 3 детей. У Гулнары среднее образование, имеет очень хорошие отзывы от своих соседей. Они отзываются о ней как о доброй и трудолюбивой женщине. Гулнара в качестве основного дохода для своей семьи, на протяжении 27 лет занимается  животноводством и полеводством. В хозяйстве есть 2 дойные коровы, 2 нетели, 10 овец и 2 лошади. Скот в живом виде она реализует на местном рынке, также продает молочную продукцию.  Дополнительно у Гулнары есть земельный надел мерою 1,04 ГА, где она посеяла картофель  и зерновые культуры для собственного потребления и реализации. Начав этот бизнес с 7,000 сом (KGS), благодаря упорному труду Гулнары, ее деятельность приносит около 9,000 сом (KGS) в месяц, что служит основой для покрытия расходов на питание и бытовые нужды семьи. В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Гулнара обратилась в Банк «Бай –Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS) на покупку двух бычков для дальнейшей перепродажи. Доходы от кредита Гулнара планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение своего бизнеса, а также в будущем хочет купить квартиру.
texts.en: Gulnara is 45 years old, married and a mother of 3 children. Gulnara has a secondary education and receives positive feedback from her neighbors. They speak of her as a kind and hardworking woman. To provide the primary source of income for her family, Gulnara has been involved in animal husbandry and farming for 27 years. Her business contains 2 dairy cows, 10 sheep, and 2 horses. She sells live livestock and milk products at a local market. Additionally, Gulnara has a 1.04 hectare land plot, where planted potatoes and cereal crops for personal consumption. Having started this business with 7,000 som (KGS), thanks to her hard work, Gulnara now earns about 9,000 som (KGS) per month, which provides the foundation for covering expenses for food and consumer needs of the family. In order to further develop her business, Gulnara requested a loan in the amount of 50,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum" Bank to buy two bulls for future resale. Gulnara plans to invest the earnings from the loan into further increasing her business and buying an apartment in the future.

loans.use: to buy two bulls

loans.name: Adamu

texts.en: Adamu remembers not being able to pay school fees  during a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Adamu, like all Babban Gona members,  can earn up to $2000/ha this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Adamu  is ambitious and is aiming to reap 35 bags per hectare this season.  “In 5 years, I want to make more money for myself and my family” expressed Adamu   With this loan, Adamu is well on his way to achieving  this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.
